Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5J47-CTG1-JBHT-D19Y-00000-00Bloomberg's David Kirkpatrick is Intvd on Bloomb Surveil2014-09-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:25:22ZLexisNexisBloomberg's David Kirkpatrick is Intvd on Bloomb SurveilLanhamFULL TEXT

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

DAVID KIRKPATRICK, BLOOMBERG CONTRIBUTING EDITOR, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG SURVEILLANCE

SEPTEMBER 19, 2014

SPEAKERS: DAVID KIRKPATRICK, BLOOMBERG CONTRIBUTING EDITOR

ADAM JOHNSON, BLOOMBERG NEWS

TOM KEENE, BLOOMBERG NEWS

SCARLET FU, BLOOMBERG NEWS

DONALD STRASZHEIM, SENIOR MANAGING DIRECTOR, ISI CHINA RESEARCH TEAM

STEVEN ODLAND, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, THE COMMITTEE FOR ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT

[*] TOM KEENE, HOST, BLOOMBERG NEWS: We've got a wonderful set of hosts for you to give you perspective and context this morning on Bloomberg Surveillance. Tobias Levkovich with us, Chief US Equity Strategist, Citi Research. We'll talk to him about this equity market that go, go, goes.

David Kirkpatrick in celebration of every big tech IPO, thank you so much for joining me it seems, every time--

DAVID KIRKPATRICK, BLOOMBERG CONTRIBUTING EDITOR: Oh I thought you just had me because my last name was Kirkpatrick.

KEENE: No, well very good. Happy Scotland to you this morning. When I look David at the Alibaba experience, everybody's going to gain a pop. From a tech standpoint, what does Fidelity or BlackRock or Capital Guardian Trust in Los Angeles, what do these big hitters do with their shares if we see the pop I think we're going to get?

KIRKPATRICK: I don't know what you mean by from a tech standpoint.

KEENE: Well from your perspective they're not going to sell are they?

KIRKPATRICK: I would not sell. I mean I think this is a company with a lot of profits which is one reason why those ratios are so favorable. And I think it is a company that has tremendous prospects. On the other hand we could talk about as we go on, there are a complicated set of issues with a company that's truly Chinese that's trying to operate globally competing with these American colossi. And you know a company that has a lot of interesting issues about finance and it's operating in a banking business.

KEENE: Right. Did Fidelity buy, to just use one name, did they acquire Alibaba because of the Chinese and Asian experience or did they buy them because they think they're going to compete in the United States?

KIRKPATRICK: I think it's both. I mean China is a continuingly huge market opportunity for Alibaba and all the Chinese internet companies. And the ratio of Chinese who are on the internet is way more than in the United States.

KEENE: Right.

KIRKPATRICK: It's still under 50% of all Chinese even on the internet. Alibaba completely dominates--

KEENE: Yeah.

KIRKPATRICK: Online e-commerce in China. So there's an opportunity there. And they want to go global.

KEENE: And you know Adam within this conversation we're going to see it open, there's going to be the green shoe with some 15% of shares.

ADAM JOHNSON, HOST, BLOOMBERG TELEVISION: Right.

KEENE: This is a different beast to institutions than any other deal you and I have seen. We've never seen this.

JOHNSON: Well for starters it's the biggest one. And if that green shoe that you talk about actually is incorporated into the deal, it will be the biggest ever in history, globally. I understand from that point of view David, just the sheer size, why a Fidelity has to be there. It's that big.

But what matters more the fact that it's that big or the fact that, in other words selling more products than Amazon and eBay or the fact that it actually can grow from here?

KIRKPATRICK: Well I mean obviously you want growth if you buy stock. So clearly that's the most important thing.

JOHNSON: In other words don't think of this as a dividend play or we've got to own it just because it's big.

KIRKPATRICK: No. I think this is a bet on the future of the global internet and connectivity as a driving force for the global economy. And Alibaba is as well-positioned as anybody for that. And that's the central force in the global economy.

0611

(BREAK)

0619

KEENE: I want to go to the froth of the moment. Let's bring up this archive photograph. This is a Surveillance archive, it's in our museum, the Surveillance museum here. There's Kirkpatrick on the left side and Kedrosky, Kirkpatrick's happier because he loaded the boat on Facebook at $38.

SCARLET FU, HOST, BLOOMBERG NEWS: Look how young you are Tom.

KEENE: Yeah I'm the dork in the middle (inaudible). This was a (inaudible) moment. Compare the froth of this moment versus what you and Paul Kedrosky helped me with that day with Facebook.

KIRKPATRICK: That's an interesting question Tom because for years I've been fascinated by the Chinese internet. I've been to China a lot, I'm lucky that way. And I've, but for years talking about it, people are like Ali- who? Ten-what?

KEENE: Yeah.

KIRKPATRICK: You know they just didn't focus on it. It's astonishing to me that the world has focused as completely on this recently obscure company as they have. I don't think it's inappropriate. Comparing it to Facebook, in the US it's not nearly comparable because ordinary Americans were bananas over Facebook IPO. And as many of the articles have pointed out most ordinary Americans still haven't even heard of Alibaba.

But could I just weigh in on a couple of these key points?

KEENE: Please.

KIRKPATRICK: First of all, you know, regulatory risk is not even the word I'd use. It's like executive fiat. That's the way China works. And if you look at how Tencent, Alibaba's biggest rival just got a banking license to be a private bank, one of the first private banks that's ever existed in China. There are only a couple ever. And Alibaba wanted one. They haven't gotten it yet. So those kinds of things are where you really can't predict what happens.

KEENE: Fabulous.

FU: All right lots of unknowns there. David Kirkpatrick one of our guest hosts for the hour and Don Straszheim, thank you so much, Don of ISI.

DONALD STRASZHEIM, SENIOR MANAGING DIRECTOR, ISI CHINA RESEARCH TEAM: Scarlet, good, you're welcome.

FU: Joining us this morning.

0620

(BREAK)

0652

KEENE: Does everybody realize David Kirkpatrick just cuts into the line this morning? Right up front?

KIRKPATRICK: I can't hold a 6 Plus it's too big for me. I would never want it.

KEENE: You're not going to get a 6 Plus?

KIRKPATRICK: No I would not consider it.

FU: The Asian David Kirkpatrick would.

KIRKPATRICK: It's not going to go in my pocket.

JOHNSON: It's a small iPad.

KEENE: It's a mini-mini. I like that the mini-mini. I want a mini-mini.

KIRKPATRICK: I want a phone. Thank you.

0653

(BREAK)

0742

JOHNSON: With us David Kirkpatrick author of "The Facebook Effect." So there's clearly some sort of iPhone 6 effect going on here David. What distinguishes the iPhone 6 from everything that's come before that would cause people to wait in lines of up to 13 blocks?

KIRKPATRICK: Well clearly people have been convinced by the Android ecosystem that a bigger phone is what they want. And I'm not even sure. I think it's surprising how much enthusiasm this was, I'll tell you though as somebody with an iPhone 5, if the battery life is better I'll be happy. Maybe it's simply that.

KEENE: Joshua Tapolsky says that's the number one thing.

JOHNSON: Battery life.

KEENE: Head of our digital operation, Tapolsky with a--

KIRKPATRICK: OK so I'm not so far off then.

KEENE: No the battery's everything.

FU: Consumers in Asia are the ones who really like the larger phones, the phablets as they call them. And this is the market that Apple and every other manufacturer is trying to grow.

KIRKPATRICK: I've been surprised that the bigger model is supposedly selling faster.

KEENE: Yeah I like the phrase a mini-mini.

JOHNSON: And the other--

KEENE: It's a mini-mini.

JOHNSON: It's a mini iPad mini.

KEENE: It's a mini-mini.

0743

(BREAK)

0744

KEENE: Here's a reality financially. David Kirkpatrick revenue growth at Apple up 79%, up 66%, up 45%, up 9%, up 5%. There's a trend there to a big blue chip, 5%, 6% revenue growth. Which is important here, the mass and the size of the existing Apple or do they really need to get marginal growth out of these two products?

KIRKPATRICK: I think they're both important. I mean this product is clearly remaking their image. I think it's, for whatever reason, they are, it's way beyond fashion. But fashion is an important part of it. Android has gigantic market share but it really is a way second class product system than what Apple has. I think Apple has reasserted it's capability to be the dominant technology producer in the world.

FU: And a lot of people believe it because they're lining up as well.

0745

(BREAK)

0750

FU: David Kirkpatrick?

KIRKPATRICK: Well you know it's also Safra Catz who's really been--

KEENE: Yes.

KIRKPATRICK: Sort of quietly the COO for a long, long time.

KEENE: Fair, fair.

KIRKPATRICK: And I honestly don't think that Larry Ellison's really stepping away that far. He's a guy that loves to sail. He loves to build Japanese houses. You know he is clearly; he has been somewhat off the campus for some time. But he's now going to be Executive Chairman and CTO. He's not going away.

KEENE: Scarlet he bought Lanai, one of the beautiful islands in Hawaii--

FU: Yes he did.

KEENE: From David Murdoch. He's buying Taiwan next week.

FU: Probably.

KIRKPATRICK: He could.

FU: Well Safra Catz is going to be one of the CEOs, the other one of course Mark Hurd. This Co-CEO arrangement Steve, I've got to wonder, isn't it a recipe for disaster? Deutsche Bank had co-CEOs and it hasn't worked out very well.

STEVEN ODLAND, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, THE COMMITTEE FOR ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT: Well there's an old saw that everybody deserves only one boss. In this case the company has two. But I suspect that they're going in understanding very clearly what the lines of division are in terms of who's going to focus on what. And I think the point is right, that Larry's not going away.

KIRKPATRICK: He will adjudicate if there's any issues with the (inaudible).

KEENE: Can I ask you guys about cloud? I mean Oracle, John Chambers--

KIRKPATRICK: That's the question.

KEENE: Cisco and others, David Kirkpatrick, make us smarter on this.

KIRKPATRICK: Well honestly this is the one thing you have to ask about Oracle, they have done a great job getting service revenues from the companies that they acquired with this annuity (ph) thing.

KEENE: Right.

KIRKPATRICK: But the real annuity in enterprise software going forward is long-term contracts for cloud revenue where you don't have to, where the customer has a way more advantageous position because they don't have to make a big upfront payment. And that's where the industry has gone with salesforce and others and Oracle is not there to the same degree.

JOHNSON: Isn't that what we saw with semis where the way to make money in semiconductors is become a fabulous semi, you just design the things and you subcontract to other people.

KIRKPATRICK: It's a good analogy actually yeah. But I think Oracle is making the shift but they're making it slowly because they have such an incredible business in the old legacy business model.

ODLAND: You know one thing that people don't understand and as a CEO at Office Depot I put in the Oracle Suite, it took years to get it in. You don't want to take that thing out. So people say, well he's building a business--

KIRKPATRICK: That's a key point.

ODLAND: You're building the business on these acquisitions. But these acquisitions create this linear integrated system that is very sticky. And it's hard to move.

JOHNSON: And by the way every year you had to pay additional amounts of money to "update it" et cetera.

KIRKPATRICK: Enterprise software is the roach motel is the ultimate goal.

FU: But that was preferable to having to go to the cloud. Shift everything over to a brand new platform wasn't it?

ODLAND: No that's right. These transformations are really expensive and really dangerous and hard.

KEENE: I want to rip up the script here. I learn things on Twitter.

JOHNSON: Yep.

KEENE: And one of our listeners and viewers sent in a brilliant Twitter response. Why wouldn't Alibaba and Amazon do some kind of JV? Steve? Is that feasible?

ODLAND: Look I think, why is Jack Ma here meeting every major CEO and financier in town? Why is he spending so much time in America when it's a Chinese IPO? I think the answer is that his focus is not just on China. His focus is on the US next.

KIRKPATRICK: It's also because he's not selling sharing shares to people in China by the way. They can't even buy this offering. That's one of the oddities of this whole thing. But I do think a JV with Amazon is not out of the question.

I think Jack Ma is the kind of opportunist in a good way, that would allow him to consider anything.

KEENE: It gives Bezos immediate international expansion right?

KIRKPATRICK: Well it could, I would, Bezos is not, I would be more surprised if Bezos did it than if Jack Ma did it.

KEENE: OK fair.

KIRKPATRICK: Bezos is not the kind of guy who likes to share the spotlight. Or who likes to really let somebody else make any decisions for him. Amazon more than almost any tech company has always wanted to do everything itself.

JOHNSON: All right so that's the theoretical. Let's get practical here. Your Office Depot that you ran through what, 2010, what does Alibaba mean for brick and mortar companies like Office Depot?

ODLAND: Well what people don't realize is that the office product stores, Office Depot and Staples, were the third and fourth largest internet retailers in the world. And so you know, there's, bricks and mortar have really increased their business.

So Alibaba is an access point I think for bricks and mortar retail into China, like Amazon had become an access point with their stores within a stores. It could be a big growth vehicle for a lot of American companies.

KIRKPATRICK: Interestingly one of the big trends in the Chinese internet is that Alibaba, Tencent and other companies are making investments in bricks and mortar. And in fact they're starting to build infrastructures that include offline delivery; both Alibaba and Tencent have been doing things with gas stations, with retail stores, where they build partnerships with cross ownership.

FU: Yeah it's not something that you hear about too much. This move into the whole physical space here for these companies.

KIRKPATRICK: It's a whole new development.

0754

(BREAK)

0757

KIRKPATRICK: Let's face it Apple technology is still way better.

KEENE: The ecosystem.

JOHNSON: OK is that honest, is that an analytical quantitative or qualitative--

KIRKPATRICK: I think it's both. I think all the evidence shows that Apple has a better design systems. People like it better. The software, hardware integration is way, dramatically better. Because that's the problem that Android has. The hardware and software is not controlled by the same people.

FU: I know Steve is going to, right after Surveillance, break out to the Apple Store because someone's holding his place in line right?

KEENE: Can we say thank you to our team? What a great set of guests today.

JOHNSON: Yes.

KEENE: Adam Posen was lousy, other than that.

FU: Oh come on. Steve Odland, thank you so much.

JOHNSON: Our producers outdid themselves today.

FU: Former CEO of Office Depot. David Kirkpatrick as well.

0758

[*] ***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

urn:contentItem:5J28-M181-JBHT-D3TH-00000-00Bloomberg's David Kirkpatrick is Intvd on Bloomb Surveil2014-09-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:25:21ZLexisNexisBloomberg's David Kirkpatrick is Intvd on Bloomb SurveilWalthamFULL TEXT

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

DAVID KIRKPATRICK, BLOOMBERG CONTRIBUTING EDITOR, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERGSURVEILLANCE

SEPTEMBER 19, 2014

SPEAKERS: DAVID KIRKPATRICK, BLOOMBERG CONTRIBUTING EDITOR

ADAM JOHNSON, BLOOMBERG NEWS

TOM KEENE, BLOOMBERG NEWS

SCARLET FU, BLOOMBERG NEWS

DONALD STRASZHEIM, SENIOR MANAGING DIRECTOR, ISI CHINA RESEARCH TEAM

STEVEN ODLAND, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, THE COMMITTEE FOR ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT

[*] TOM KEENE, HOST, BLOOMBERG NEWS: We've got a wonderful set of hosts for you to give you perspective and context this morning on BloombergSurveillance. Tobias Levkovich with us, Chief US Equity Strategist, Citi Research. We'll talk to him about this equity market that go, go, goes.

David Kirkpatrick in celebration of every big tech IPO, thank you so much for joining me it seems, every time--

DAVID KIRKPATRICK, BLOOMBERG CONTRIBUTING EDITOR: Oh I thought you just had me because my last name was Kirkpatrick.

KEENE: No, well very good. Happy Scotland to you this morning. When I look David at the Alibaba experience, everybody's going to gain a pop. From a tech standpoint, what does Fidelity or BlackRock or Capital Guardian Trust in Los Angeles, what do these big hitters do with their shares if we see the pop I think we're going to get?

KIRKPATRICK: I don't know what you mean by from a tech standpoint.

KEENE: Well from your perspective they're not going to sell are they?

KIRKPATRICK: I would not sell. I mean I think this is a company with a lot of profits which is one reason why those ratios are so favorable. And I think it is a company that has tremendous prospects. On the other hand we could talk about as we go on, there are a complicated set of issues with a company that's truly Chinese that's trying to operate globally competing with these American colossi. And you know a company that has a lot of interesting issues about finance and it's operating in a banking business.

KEENE: Right. Did Fidelity buy, to just use one name, did they acquire Alibaba because of the Chinese and Asian experience or did they buy them because they think they're going to compete in the United States?

KIRKPATRICK: I think it's both. I mean China is a continuingly huge market opportunity for Alibaba and all the Chinese internet companies. And the ratio of Chinese who are on the internet is way more than in the United States.

KEENE: Right.

KIRKPATRICK: It's still under 50% of all Chinese even on the internet. Alibaba completely dominates--

KEENE: Yeah.

KIRKPATRICK: Online e-commerce in China. So there's an opportunity there. And they want to go global.

KEENE: And you know Adam within this conversation we're going to see it open, there's going to be the green shoe with some 15% of shares.

ADAM JOHNSON, HOST, BLOOMBERG TELEVISION: Right.

KEENE: This is a different beast to institutions than any other deal you and I have seen. We've never seen this.

JOHNSON: Well for starters it's the biggest one. And if that green shoe that you talk about actually is incorporated into the deal, it will be the biggest ever in history, globally. I understand from that point of view David, just the sheer size, why a Fidelity has to be there. It's that big.

But what matters more the fact that it's that big or the fact that, in other words selling more products than Amazon and eBay or the fact that it actually can grow from here?

KIRKPATRICK: Well I mean obviously you want growth if you buy stock. So clearly that's the most important thing.

JOHNSON: In other words don't think of this as a dividend play or we've got to own it just because it's big.

KIRKPATRICK: No. I think this is a bet on the future of the global internet and connectivity as a driving force for the global economy. And Alibaba is as well-positioned as anybody for that. And that's the central force in the global economy.

0611

(BREAK)

0619

KEENE: I want to go to the froth of the moment. Let's bring up this archive photograph. This is a Surveillance archive, it's in our museum, the Surveillance museum here. There's Kirkpatrick on the left side and Kedrosky, Kirkpatrick's happier because he loaded the boat on Facebook at $38.

SCARLET FU, HOST, BLOOMBERG NEWS: Look how young you are Tom.

KEENE: Yeah I'm the dork in the middle (inaudible). This was a (inaudible) moment. Compare the froth of this moment versus what you and Paul Kedrosky helped me with that day with Facebook.

KIRKPATRICK: That's an interesting question Tom because for years I've been fascinated by the Chinese internet. I've been to China a lot, I'm lucky that way. And I've, but for years talking about it, people are like Ali- who? Ten-what?

KEENE: Yeah.

KIRKPATRICK: You know they just didn't focus on it. It's astonishing to me that the world has focused as completely on this recently obscure company as they have. I don't think it's inappropriate. Comparing it to Facebook, in the US it's not nearly comparable because ordinary Americans were bananas over Facebook IPO. And as many of the articles have pointed out most ordinary Americans still haven't even heard of Alibaba.

But could I just weigh in on a couple of these key points?

KEENE: Please.

KIRKPATRICK: First of all, you know, regulatory risk is not even the word I'd use. It's like executive fiat. That's the way China works. And if you look at how Tencent, Alibaba's biggest rival just got a banking license to be a private bank, one of the first private banks that's ever existed in China. There are only a couple ever. And Alibaba wanted one. They haven't gotten it yet. So those kinds of things are where you really can't predict what happens.

KEENE: Fabulous.

FU: All right lots of unknowns there. David Kirkpatrick one of our guest hosts for the hour and Don Straszheim, thank you so much, Don of ISI.

DONALD STRASZHEIM, SENIOR MANAGING DIRECTOR, ISI CHINA RESEARCH TEAM: Scarlet, good, you're welcome.

FU: Joining us this morning.

0620

(BREAK)

0652

KEENE: Does everybody realize David Kirkpatrick just cuts into the line this morning? Right up front?

KIRKPATRICK: I can't hold a 6 Plus it's too big for me. I would never want it.

KEENE: You're not going to get a 6 Plus?

KIRKPATRICK: No I would not consider it.

FU: The Asian David Kirkpatrick would.

KIRKPATRICK: It's not going to go in my pocket.

JOHNSON: It's a small iPad.

KEENE: It's a mini-mini. I like that the mini-mini. I want a mini-mini.

KIRKPATRICK: I want a phone. Thank you.

0653

(BREAK)

0742

JOHNSON: With us David Kirkpatrick author of "The Facebook Effect." So there's clearly some sort of iPhone 6 effect going on here David. What distinguishes the iPhone 6 from everything that's come before that would cause people to wait in lines of up to 13 blocks?

KIRKPATRICK: Well clearly people have been convinced by the Android ecosystem that a bigger phone is what they want. And I'm not even sure. I think it's surprising how much enthusiasm this was, I'll tell you though as somebody with an iPhone 5, if the battery life is better I'll be happy. Maybe it's simply that.

KEENE: Joshua Tapolsky says that's the number one thing.

JOHNSON: Battery life.

KEENE: Head of our digital operation, Tapolsky with a--

KIRKPATRICK: OK so I'm not so far off then.

KEENE: No the battery's everything.

FU: Consumers in Asia are the ones who really like the larger phones, the phablets as they call them. And this is the market that Apple and every other manufacturer is trying to grow.

KIRKPATRICK: I've been surprised that the bigger model is supposedly selling faster.

KEENE: Yeah I like the phrase a mini-mini.

JOHNSON: And the other--

KEENE: It's a mini-mini.

JOHNSON: It's a mini iPad mini.

KEENE: It's a mini-mini.

0743

(BREAK)

0744

KEENE: Here's a reality financially. David Kirkpatrick revenue growth at Apple up 79%, up 66%, up 45%, up 9%, up 5%. There's a trend there to a big blue chip, 5%, 6% revenue growth. Which is important here, the mass and the size of the existing Apple or do they really need to get marginal growth out of these two products?

KIRKPATRICK: I think they're both important. I mean this product is clearly remaking their image. I think it's, for whatever reason, they are, it's way beyond fashion. But fashion is an important part of it. Android has gigantic market share but it really is a way second class product system than what Apple has. I think Apple has reasserted it's capability to be the dominant technology producer in the world.

FU: And a lot of people believe it because they're lining up as well.

0745

(BREAK)

0750

FU: David Kirkpatrick?

KIRKPATRICK: Well you know it's also Safra Catz who's really been--

KEENE: Yes.

KIRKPATRICK: Sort of quietly the COO for a long, long time.

KEENE: Fair, fair.

KIRKPATRICK: And I honestly don't think that Larry Ellison's really stepping away that far. He's a guy that loves to sail. He loves to build Japanese houses. You know he is clearly; he has been somewhat off the campus for some time. But he's now going to be Executive Chairman and CTO. He's not going away.

KEENE: Scarlet he bought Lanai, one of the beautiful islands in Hawaii--

FU: Yes he did.

KEENE: From David Murdoch. He's buying Taiwan next week.

FU: Probably.

KIRKPATRICK: He could.

FU: Well Safra Catz is going to be one of the CEOs, the other one of course Mark Hurd. This Co-CEO arrangement Steve, I've got to wonder, isn't it a recipe for disaster? Deutsche Bank had co-CEOs and it hasn't worked out very well.

STEVEN ODLAND, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, THE COMMITTEE FOR ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT: Well there's an old saw that everybody deserves only one boss. In this case the company has two. But I suspect that they're going in understanding very clearly what the lines of division are in terms of who's going to focus on what. And I think the point is right, that Larry's not going away.

KIRKPATRICK: He will adjudicate if there's any issues with the (inaudible).

KEENE: Can I ask you guys about cloud? I mean Oracle, John Chambers--

KIRKPATRICK: That's the question.

KEENE: Cisco and others, David Kirkpatrick, make us smarter on this.

KIRKPATRICK: Well honestly this is the one thing you have to ask about Oracle, they have done a great job getting service revenues from the companies that they acquired with this annuity (ph) thing.

KEENE: Right.

KIRKPATRICK: But the real annuity in enterprise software going forward is long-term contracts for cloud revenue where you don't have to, where the customer has a way more advantageous position because they don't have to make a big upfront payment. And that's where the industry has gone with salesforce and others and Oracle is not there to the same degree.

JOHNSON: Isn't that what we saw with semis where the way to make money in semiconductors is become a fabulous semi, you just design the things and you subcontract to other people.

KIRKPATRICK: It's a good analogy actually yeah. But I think Oracle is making the shift but they're making it slowly because they have such an incredible business in the old legacy business model.

ODLAND: You know one thing that people don't understand and as a CEO at Office Depot I put in the Oracle Suite, it took years to get it in. You don't want to take that thing out. So people say, well he's building a business--

KIRKPATRICK: That's a key point.

ODLAND: You're building the business on these acquisitions. But these acquisitions create this linear integrated system that is very sticky. And it's hard to move.

JOHNSON: And by the way every year you had to pay additional amounts of money to "update it" et cetera.

KIRKPATRICK: Enterprise software is the roach motel is the ultimate goal.

FU: But that was preferable to having to go to the cloud. Shift everything over to a brand new platform wasn't it?

ODLAND: No that's right. These transformations are really expensive and really dangerous and hard.

KEENE: I want to rip up the script here. I learn things on Twitter.

JOHNSON: Yep.

KEENE: And one of our listeners and viewers sent in a brilliant Twitter response. Why wouldn't Alibaba and Amazon do some kind of JV? Steve? Is that feasible?

ODLAND: Look I think, why is Jack Ma here meeting every major CEO and financier in town? Why is he spending so much time in America when it's a Chinese IPO? I think the answer is that his focus is not just on China. His focus is on the US next.

KIRKPATRICK: It's also because he's not selling sharing shares to people in China by the way. They can't even buy this offering. That's one of the oddities of this whole thing. But I do think a JV with Amazon is not out of the question.

I think Jack Ma is the kind of opportunist in a good way, that would allow him to consider anything.

KEENE: It gives Bezos immediate international expansion right?

KIRKPATRICK: Well it could, I would, Bezos is not, I would be more surprised if Bezos did it than if Jack Ma did it.

KEENE: OK fair.

KIRKPATRICK: Bezos is not the kind of guy who likes to share the spotlight. Or who likes to really let somebody else make any decisions for him. Amazon more than almost any tech company has always wanted to do everything itself.

JOHNSON: All right so that's the theoretical. Let's get practical here. Your Office Depot that you ran through what, 2010, what does Alibaba mean for brick and mortar companies like Office Depot?

ODLAND: Well what people don't realize is that the office product stores, Office Depot and Staples, were the third and fourth largest internet retailers in the world. And so you know, there's, bricks and mortar have really increased their business.

So Alibaba is an access point I think for bricks and mortar retail into China, like Amazon had become an access point with their stores within a stores. It could be a big growth vehicle for a lot of American companies.

KIRKPATRICK: Interestingly one of the big trends in the Chinese internet is that Alibaba, Tencent and other companies are making investments in bricks and mortar. And in fact they're starting to build infrastructures that include offline delivery; both Alibaba and Tencent have been doing things with gas stations, with retail stores, where they build partnerships with cross ownership.

FU: Yeah it's not something that you hear about too much. This move into the whole physical space here for these companies.

KIRKPATRICK: It's a whole new development.

0754

(BREAK)

0757

KIRKPATRICK: Let's face it Apple technology is still way better.

KEENE: The ecosystem.

JOHNSON: OK is that honest, is that an analytical quantitative or qualitative--

KIRKPATRICK: I think it's both. I think all the evidence shows that Apple has a better design systems. People like it better. The software, hardware integration is way, dramatically better. Because that's the problem that Android has. The hardware and software is not controlled by the same people.

FU: I know Steve is going to, right after Surveillance, break out to the Apple Store because someone's holding his place in line right?

KEENE: Can we say thank you to our team? What a great set of guests today.

JOHNSON: Yes.

KEENE: Adam Posen was lousy, other than that.

FU: Oh come on. Steve Odland, thank you so much.

JOHNSON: Our producers outdid themselves today.

FU: Former CEO of Office Depot. David Kirkpatrick as well.

0758

[*] ***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

urn:contentItem:5D5Y-PF31-JD2T-F3RX-00000-00Bloomberg's David Kirkpatrick is Intvd on Bloomb Surveil2014-09-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:25:21ZLexisNexisBloomberg's David Kirkpatrick is Intvd on Bloomb Surveil

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

DAVID KIRKPATRICK, BLOOMBERG CONTRIBUTING EDITOR, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERGSURVEILLANCE

SEPTEMBER 19, 2014

SPEAKERS: DAVID KIRKPATRICK, BLOOMBERG CONTRIBUTING EDITOR

ADAM JOHNSON, BLOOMBERG NEWS

TOM KEENE, BLOOMBERG NEWS

SCARLET FU, BLOOMBERG NEWS

DONALD STRASZHEIM, SENIOR MANAGING DIRECTOR, ISI CHINA RESEARCH TEAM

STEVEN ODLAND, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, THE COMMITTEE FOR ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT

[*] TOM KEENE, HOST, BLOOMBERG NEWS: We've got a wonderful set of hosts for you to give you perspective and context this morning on BloombergSurveillance. Tobias Levkovich with us, Chief US Equity Strategist, Citi Research. We'll talk to him about this equity market that go, go, goes.

David Kirkpatrick in celebration of every big tech IPO, thank you so much for joining me it seems, every time--

DAVID KIRKPATRICK, BLOOMBERG CONTRIBUTING EDITOR: Oh I thought you just had me because my last name was Kirkpatrick.

KEENE: No, well very good. Happy Scotland to you this morning. When I look David at the Alibaba experience, everybody's going to gain a pop. From a tech standpoint, what does Fidelity or BlackRock or Capital Guardian Trust in Los Angeles, what do these big hitters do with their shares if we see the pop I think we're going to get?

KIRKPATRICK: I don't know what you mean by from a tech standpoint.

KEENE: Well from your perspective they're not going to sell are they?

KIRKPATRICK: I would not sell. I mean I think this is a company with a lot of profits which is one reason why those ratios are so favorable. And I think it is a company that has tremendous prospects. On the other hand we could talk about as we go on, there are a complicated set of issues with a company that's truly Chinese that's trying to operate globally competing with these American colossi. And you know a company that has a lot of interesting issues about finance and it's operating in a banking business.

KEENE: Right. Did Fidelity buy, to just use one name, did they acquire Alibaba because of the Chinese and Asian experience or did they buy them because they think they're going to compete in the United States?

KIRKPATRICK: I think it's both. I mean China is a continuingly huge market opportunity for Alibaba and all the Chinese internet companies. And the ratio of Chinese who are on the internet is way more than in the United States.

KEENE: Right.

KIRKPATRICK: It's still under 50% of all Chinese even on the internet. Alibaba completely dominates--

KEENE: Yeah.

KIRKPATRICK: Online e-commerce in China. So there's an opportunity there. And they want to go global.

KEENE: And you know Adam within this conversation we're going to see it open, there's going to be the green shoe with some 15% of shares.

ADAM JOHNSON, HOST, BLOOMBERG TELEVISION: Right.

KEENE: This is a different beast to institutions than any other deal you and I have seen. We've never seen this.

JOHNSON: Well for starters it's the biggest one. And if that green shoe that you talk about actually is incorporated into the deal, it will be the biggest ever in history, globally. I understand from that point of view David, just the sheer size, why a Fidelity has to be there. It's that big.

But what matters more the fact that it's that big or the fact that, in other words selling more products than Amazon and eBay or the fact that it actually can grow from here?

KIRKPATRICK: Well I mean obviously you want growth if you buy stock. So clearly that's the most important thing.

JOHNSON: In other words don't think of this as a dividend play or we've got to own it just because it's big.

KIRKPATRICK: No. I think this is a bet on the future of the global internet and connectivity as a driving force for the global economy. And Alibaba is as well-positioned as anybody for that. And that's the central force in the global economy.

0611

(BREAK)

0619

KEENE: I want to go to the froth of the moment. Let's bring up this archive photograph. This is a Surveillance archive, it's in our museum, the Surveillance museum here. There's Kirkpatrick on the left side and Kedrosky, Kirkpatrick's happier because he loaded the boat on Facebook at $38.

SCARLET FU, HOST, BLOOMBERG NEWS: Look how young you are Tom.

KEENE: Yeah I'm the dork in the middle (inaudible). This was a (inaudible) moment. Compare the froth of this moment versus what you and Paul Kedrosky helped me with that day with Facebook.

KIRKPATRICK: That's an interesting question Tom because for years I've been fascinated by the Chinese internet. I've been to China a lot, I'm lucky that way. And I've, but for years talking about it, people are like Ali- who? Ten-what?

KEENE: Yeah.

KIRKPATRICK: You know they just didn't focus on it. It's astonishing to me that the world has focused as completely on this recently obscure company as they have. I don't think it's inappropriate. Comparing it to Facebook, in the US it's not nearly comparable because ordinary Americans were bananas over Facebook IPO. And as many of the articles have pointed out most ordinary Americans still haven't even heard of Alibaba.

But could I just weigh in on a couple of these key points?

KEENE: Please.

KIRKPATRICK: First of all, you know, regulatory risk is not even the word I'd use. It's like executive fiat. That's the way China works. And if you look at how Tencent, Alibaba's biggest rival just got a banking license to be a private bank, one of the first private banks that's ever existed in China. There are only a couple ever. And Alibaba wanted one. They haven't gotten it yet. So those kinds of things are where you really can't predict what happens.

KEENE: Fabulous.

FU: All right lots of unknowns there. David Kirkpatrick one of our guest hosts for the hour and Don Straszheim, thank you so much, Don of ISI.

DONALD STRASZHEIM, SENIOR MANAGING DIRECTOR, ISI CHINA RESEARCH TEAM: Scarlet, good, you're welcome.

FU: Joining us this morning.

0620

(BREAK)

0652

KEENE: Does everybody realize David Kirkpatrick just cuts into the line this morning? Right up front?

KIRKPATRICK: I can't hold a 6 Plus it's too big for me. I would never want it.

KEENE: You're not going to get a 6 Plus?

KIRKPATRICK: No I would not consider it.

FU: The Asian David Kirkpatrick would.

KIRKPATRICK: It's not going to go in my pocket.

JOHNSON: It's a small iPad.

KEENE: It's a mini-mini. I like that the mini-mini. I want a mini-mini.

KIRKPATRICK: I want a phone. Thank you.

0653

(BREAK)

0742

JOHNSON: With us David Kirkpatrick author of "The Facebook Effect." So there's clearly some sort of iPhone 6 effect going on here David. What distinguishes the iPhone 6 from everything that's come before that would cause people to wait in lines of up to 13 blocks?

KIRKPATRICK: Well clearly people have been convinced by the Android ecosystem that a bigger phone is what they want. And I'm not even sure. I think it's surprising how much enthusiasm this was, I'll tell you though as somebody with an iPhone 5, if the battery life is better I'll be happy. Maybe it's simply that.

KEENE: Joshua Tapolsky says that's the number one thing.

JOHNSON: Battery life.

KEENE: Head of our digital operation, Tapolsky with a--

KIRKPATRICK: OK so I'm not so far off then.

KEENE: No the battery's everything.

FU: Consumers in Asia are the ones who really like the larger phones, the phablets as they call them. And this is the market that Apple and every other manufacturer is trying to grow.

KIRKPATRICK: I've been surprised that the bigger model is supposedly selling faster.

KEENE: Yeah I like the phrase a mini-mini.

JOHNSON: And the other--

KEENE: It's a mini-mini.

JOHNSON: It's a mini iPad mini.

KEENE: It's a mini-mini.

0743

(BREAK)

0744

KEENE: Here's a reality financially. David Kirkpatrick revenue growth at Apple up 79%, up 66%, up 45%, up 9%, up 5%. There's a trend there to a big blue chip, 5%, 6% revenue growth. Which is important here, the mass and the size of the existing Apple or do they really need to get marginal growth out of these two products?

KIRKPATRICK: I think they're both important. I mean this product is clearly remaking their image. I think it's, for whatever reason, they are, it's way beyond fashion. But fashion is an important part of it. Android has gigantic market share but it really is a way second class product system than what Apple has. I think Apple has reasserted it's capability to be the dominant technology producer in the world.

FU: And a lot of people believe it because they're lining up as well.

0745

(BREAK)

0750

FU: David Kirkpatrick?

KIRKPATRICK: Well you know it's also Safra Catz who's really been--

KEENE: Yes.

KIRKPATRICK: Sort of quietly the COO for a long, long time.

KEENE: Fair, fair.

KIRKPATRICK: And I honestly don't think that Larry Ellison's really stepping away that far. He's a guy that loves to sail. He loves to build Japanese houses. You know he is clearly; he has been somewhat off the campus for some time. But he's now going to be Executive Chairman and CTO. He's not going away.

KEENE: Scarlet he bought Lanai, one of the beautiful islands in Hawaii--

FU: Yes he did.

KEENE: From David Murdoch. He's buying Taiwan next week.

FU: Probably.

KIRKPATRICK: He could.

FU: Well Safra Catz is going to be one of the CEOs, the other one of course Mark Hurd. This Co-CEO arrangement Steve, I've got to wonder, isn't it a recipe for disaster? Deutsche Bank had co-CEOs and it hasn't worked out very well.

STEVEN ODLAND, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, THE COMMITTEE FOR ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT: Well there's an old saw that everybody deserves only one boss. In this case the company has two. But I suspect that they're going in understanding very clearly what the lines of division are in terms of who's going to focus on what. And I think the point is right, that Larry's not going away.

KIRKPATRICK: He will adjudicate if there's any issues with the (inaudible).

KEENE: Can I ask you guys about cloud? I mean Oracle, John Chambers--

KIRKPATRICK: That's the question.

KEENE: Cisco and others, David Kirkpatrick, make us smarter on this.

KIRKPATRICK: Well honestly this is the one thing you have to ask about Oracle, they have done a great job getting service revenues from the companies that they acquired with this annuity (ph) thing.

KEENE: Right.

KIRKPATRICK: But the real annuity in enterprise software going forward is long-term contracts for cloud revenue where you don't have to, where the customer has a way more advantageous position because they don't have to make a big upfront payment. And that's where the industry has gone with salesforce and others and Oracle is not there to the same degree.

JOHNSON: Isn't that what we saw with semis where the way to make money in semiconductors is become a fabulous semi, you just design the things and you subcontract to other people.

KIRKPATRICK: It's a good analogy actually yeah. But I think Oracle is making the shift but they're making it slowly because they have such an incredible business in the old legacy business model.

ODLAND: You know one thing that people don't understand and as a CEO at Office Depot I put in the Oracle Suite, it took years to get it in. You don't want to take that thing out. So people say, well he's building a business--

KIRKPATRICK: That's a key point.

ODLAND: You're building the business on these acquisitions. But these acquisitions create this linear integrated system that is very sticky. And it's hard to move.

JOHNSON: And by the way every year you had to pay additional amounts of money to "update it" et cetera.

KIRKPATRICK: Enterprise software is the roach motel is the ultimate goal.

FU: But that was preferable to having to go to the cloud. Shift everything over to a brand new platform wasn't it?

ODLAND: No that's right. These transformations are really expensive and really dangerous and hard.

KEENE: I want to rip up the script here. I learn things on Twitter.

JOHNSON: Yep.

KEENE: And one of our listeners and viewers sent in a brilliant Twitter response. Why wouldn't Alibaba and Amazon do some kind of JV? Steve? Is that feasible?

ODLAND: Look I think, why is Jack Ma here meeting every major CEO and financier in town? Why is he spending so much time in America when it's a Chinese IPO? I think the answer is that his focus is not just on China. His focus is on the US next.

KIRKPATRICK: It's also because he's not selling sharing shares to people in China by the way. They can't even buy this offering. That's one of the oddities of this whole thing. But I do think a JV with Amazon is not out of the question.

I think Jack Ma is the kind of opportunist in a good way, that would allow him to consider anything.

KEENE: It gives Bezos immediate international expansion right?

KIRKPATRICK: Well it could, I would, Bezos is not, I would be more surprised if Bezos did it than if Jack Ma did it.

KEENE: OK fair.

KIRKPATRICK: Bezos is not the kind of guy who likes to share the spotlight. Or who likes to really let somebody else make any decisions for him. Amazon more than almost any tech company has always wanted to do everything itself.

JOHNSON: All right so that's the theoretical. Let's get practical here. Your Office Depot that you ran through what, 2010, what does Alibaba mean for brick and mortar companies like Office Depot?

ODLAND: Well what people don't realize is that the office product stores, Office Depot and Staples, were the third and fourth largest internet retailers in the world. And so you know, there's, bricks and mortar have really increased their business.

So Alibaba is an access point I think for bricks and mortar retail into China, like Amazon had become an access point with their stores within a stores. It could be a big growth vehicle for a lot of American companies.

KIRKPATRICK: Interestingly one of the big trends in the Chinese internet is that Alibaba, Tencent and other companies are making investments in bricks and mortar. And in fact they're starting to build infrastructures that include offline delivery; both Alibaba and Tencent have been doing things with gas stations, with retail stores, where they build partnerships with cross ownership.

FU: Yeah it's not something that you hear about too much. This move into the whole physical space here for these companies.

KIRKPATRICK: It's a whole new development.

0754

(BREAK)

0757

KIRKPATRICK: Let's face it Apple technology is still way better.

KEENE: The ecosystem.

JOHNSON: OK is that honest, is that an analytical quantitative or qualitative--

KIRKPATRICK: I think it's both. I think all the evidence shows that Apple has a better design systems. People like it better. The software, hardware integration is way, dramatically better. Because that's the problem that Android has. The hardware and software is not controlled by the same people.

FU: I know Steve is going to, right after Surveillance, break out to the Apple Store because someone's holding his place in line right?

KEENE: Can we say thank you to our team? What a great set of guests today.

JOHNSON: Yes.

KEENE: Adam Posen was lousy, other than that.

FU: Oh come on. Steve Odland, thank you so much.

JOHNSON: Our producers outdid themselves today.

FU: Former CEO of Office Depot. David Kirkpatrick as well.

0758

[*] ***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5D5S-8MS1-JB20-G45C-00000-00Bloomberg`s David Kirkpatrick is Intvd on Bloomb Surveil2014-09-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:25:21ZLexisNexisBLOOMBERG SURVEILLANCE7:00 AM ESTDavid Kirkpatrick, Donald Straszheim, Steven OdlandNEWSInternational091991cb.556Bloomberg`s David Kirkpatrick is Intvd on Bloomb SurveilAdam Johnson, Tom Keene, Scarlet Fu

David Kirkpatrick talks about technology

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

DAVID KIRKPATRICK, BLOOMBERG CONTRIBUTING EDITOR, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERGSURVEILLANCE

SEPTEMBER 19, 2014

SPEAKERS: DAVID KIRKPATRICK, BLOOMBERG CONTRIBUTING EDITOR

ADAM JOHNSON, BLOOMBERG NEWS

TOM KEENE, BLOOMBERG NEWS

SCARLET FU, BLOOMBERG NEWS

DONALD STRASZHEIM, SENIOR MANAGING DIRECTOR, ISI CHINA RESEARCH TEAM

STEVEN ODLAND, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, THE COMMITTEE FOR ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT

[*] TOM KEENE, HOST, BLOOMBERG NEWS: We've got a wonderful set of hosts for you to give you perspective and context this morning on BloombergSurveillance. Tobias Levkovich with us, Chief US Equity Strategist, Citi Research. We'll talk to him about this equity market that go, go, goes.

David Kirkpatrick in celebration of every big tech IPO, thank you so much for joining me it seems, every time--

DAVID KIRKPATRICK, BLOOMBERG CONTRIBUTING EDITOR: Oh I thought you just had me because my last name was Kirkpatrick.

KEENE: No, well very good. Happy Scotland to you this morning. When I look David at the Alibaba experience, everybody's going to gain a pop. From a tech standpoint, what does Fidelity or BlackRock or Capital Guardian Trust in Los Angeles, what do these big hitters do with their shares if we see the pop I think we're going to get?

KIRKPATRICK: I don't know what you mean by from a tech standpoint.

KEENE: Well from your perspective they're not going to sell are they?

KIRKPATRICK: I would not sell. I mean I think this is a company with a lot of profits which is one reason why those ratios are so favorable. And I think it is a company that has tremendous prospects. On the other hand we could talk about as we go on, there are a complicated set of issues with a company that's truly Chinese that's trying to operate globally competing with these American colossi. And you know a company that has a lot of interesting issues about finance and it's operating in a banking business.

KEENE: Right. Did Fidelity buy, to just use one name, did they acquire Alibaba because of the Chinese and Asian experience or did they buy them because they think they're going to compete in the United States?

KIRKPATRICK: I think it's both. I mean China is a continuingly huge market opportunity for Alibaba and all the Chinese internet companies. And the ratio of Chinese who are on the internet is way more than in the United States.

KEENE: Right.

KIRKPATRICK: It's still under 50% of all Chinese even on the internet. Alibaba completely dominates--

KEENE: Yeah.

KIRKPATRICK: Online e-commerce in China. So there's an opportunity there. And they want to go global.

KEENE: And you know Adam within this conversation we're going to see it open, there's going to be the green shoe with some 15% of shares.

ADAM JOHNSON, HOST, BLOOMBERG TELEVISION: Right.

KEENE: This is a different beast to institutions than any other deal you and I have seen. We've never seen this.

JOHNSON: Well for starters it's the biggest one. And if that green shoe that you talk about actually is incorporated into the deal, it will be the biggest ever in history, globally. I understand from that point of view David, just the sheer size, why a Fidelity has to be there. It's that big.

But what matters more the fact that it's that big or the fact that, in other words selling more products than Amazon and eBay or the fact that it actually can grow from here?

KIRKPATRICK: Well I mean obviously you want growth if you buy stock. So clearly that's the most important thing.

JOHNSON: In other words don't think of this as a dividend play or we've got to own it just because it's big.

KIRKPATRICK: No. I think this is a bet on the future of the global internet and connectivity as a driving force for the global economy. And Alibaba is as well-positioned as anybody for that. And that's the central force in the global economy.

0611

(BREAK)

0619

KEENE: I want to go to the froth of the moment. Let's bring up this archive photograph. This is a Surveillance archive, it's in our museum, the Surveillance museum here. There's Kirkpatrick on the left side and Kedrosky, Kirkpatrick's happier because he loaded the boat on Facebook at $38.

SCARLET FU, HOST, BLOOMBERG NEWS: Look how young you are Tom.

KEENE: Yeah I'm the dork in the middle (inaudible). This was a (inaudible) moment. Compare the froth of this moment versus what you and Paul Kedrosky helped me with that day with Facebook.

KIRKPATRICK: That's an interesting question Tom because for years I've been fascinated by the Chinese internet. I've been to China a lot, I'm lucky that way. And I've, but for years talking about it, people are like Ali- who? Ten-what?

KEENE: Yeah.

KIRKPATRICK: You know they just didn't focus on it. It's astonishing to me that the world has focused as completely on this recently obscure company as they have. I don't think it's inappropriate. Comparing it to Facebook, in the US it's not nearly comparable because ordinary Americans were bananas over Facebook IPO. And as many of the articles have pointed out most ordinary Americans still haven't even heard of Alibaba.

But could I just weigh in on a couple of these key points?

KEENE: Please.

KIRKPATRICK: First of all, you know, regulatory risk is not even the word I'd use. It's like executive fiat. That's the way China works. And if you look at how Tencent, Alibaba's biggest rival just got a banking license to be a private bank, one of the first private banks that's ever existed in China. There are only a couple ever. And Alibaba wanted one. They haven't gotten it yet. So those kinds of things are where you really can't predict what happens.

KEENE: Fabulous.

FU: All right lots of unknowns there. David Kirkpatrick one of our guest hosts for the hour and Don Straszheim, thank you so much, Don of ISI.

DONALD STRASZHEIM, SENIOR MANAGING DIRECTOR, ISI CHINA RESEARCH TEAM: Scarlet, good, you're welcome.

FU: Joining us this morning.

0620

(BREAK)

0652

KEENE: Does everybody realize David Kirkpatrick just cuts into the line this morning? Right up front?

KIRKPATRICK: I can't hold a 6 Plus it's too big for me. I would never want it.

KEENE: You're not going to get a 6 Plus?

KIRKPATRICK: No I would not consider it.

FU: The Asian David Kirkpatrick would.

KIRKPATRICK: It's not going to go in my pocket.

JOHNSON: It's a small iPad.

KEENE: It's a mini-mini. I like that the mini-mini. I want a mini-mini.

KIRKPATRICK: I want a phone. Thank you.

0653

(BREAK)

0742

JOHNSON: With us David Kirkpatrick author of "The Facebook Effect." So there's clearly some sort of iPhone 6 effect going on here David. What distinguishes the iPhone 6 from everything that's come before that would cause people to wait in lines of up to 13 blocks?

KIRKPATRICK: Well clearly people have been convinced by the Android ecosystem that a bigger phone is what they want. And I'm not even sure. I think it's surprising how much enthusiasm this was, I'll tell you though as somebody with an iPhone 5, if the battery life is better I'll be happy. Maybe it's simply that.

KEENE: Joshua Tapolsky says that's the number one thing.

JOHNSON: Battery life.

KEENE: Head of our digital operation, Tapolsky with a--

KIRKPATRICK: OK so I'm not so far off then.

KEENE: No the battery's everything.

FU: Consumers in Asia are the ones who really like the larger phones, the phablets as they call them. And this is the market that Apple and every other manufacturer is trying to grow.

KIRKPATRICK: I've been surprised that the bigger model is supposedly selling faster.

KEENE: Yeah I like the phrase a mini-mini.

JOHNSON: And the other--

KEENE: It's a mini-mini.

JOHNSON: It's a mini iPad mini.

KEENE: It's a mini-mini.

0743

(BREAK)

0744

KEENE: Here's a reality financially. David Kirkpatrick revenue growth at Apple up 79%, up 66%, up 45%, up 9%, up 5%. There's a trend there to a big blue chip, 5%, 6% revenue growth. Which is important here, the mass and the size of the existing Apple or do they really need to get marginal growth out of these two products?

KIRKPATRICK: I think they're both important. I mean this product is clearly remaking their image. I think it's, for whatever reason, they are, it's way beyond fashion. But fashion is an important part of it. Android has gigantic market share but it really is a way second class product system than what Apple has. I think Apple has reasserted it's capability to be the dominant technology producer in the world.

FU: And a lot of people believe it because they're lining up as well.

0745

(BREAK)

0750

FU: David Kirkpatrick?

KIRKPATRICK: Well you know it's also Safra Catz who's really been--

KEENE: Yes.

KIRKPATRICK: Sort of quietly the COO for a long, long time.

KEENE: Fair, fair.

KIRKPATRICK: And I honestly don't think that Larry Ellison's really stepping away that far. He's a guy that loves to sail. He loves to build Japanese houses. You know he is clearly; he has been somewhat off the campus for some time. But he's now going to be Executive Chairman and CTO. He's not going away.

KEENE: Scarlet he bought Lanai, one of the beautiful islands in Hawaii--

FU: Yes he did.

KEENE: From David Murdoch. He's buying Taiwan next week.

FU: Probably.

KIRKPATRICK: He could.

FU: Well Safra Catz is going to be one of the CEOs, the other one of course Mark Hurd. This Co-CEO arrangement Steve, I've got to wonder, isn't it a recipe for disaster? Deutsche Bank had co-CEOs and it hasn't worked out very well.

STEVEN ODLAND, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, THE COMMITTEE FOR ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT: Well there's an old saw that everybody deserves only one boss. In this case the company has two. But I suspect that they're going in understanding very clearly what the lines of division are in terms of who's going to focus on what. And I think the point is right, that Larry's not going away.

KIRKPATRICK: He will adjudicate if there's any issues with the (inaudible).

KEENE: Can I ask you guys about cloud? I mean Oracle, John Chambers--

KIRKPATRICK: That's the question.

KEENE: Cisco and others, David Kirkpatrick, make us smarter on this.

KIRKPATRICK: Well honestly this is the one thing you have to ask about Oracle, they have done a great job getting service revenues from the companies that they acquired with this annuity (ph) thing.

KEENE: Right.

KIRKPATRICK: But the real annuity in enterprise software going forward is long-term contracts for cloud revenue where you don't have to, where the customer has a way more advantageous position because they don't have to make a big upfront payment. And that's where the industry has gone with salesforce and others and Oracle is not there to the same degree.

JOHNSON: Isn't that what we saw with semis where the way to make money in semiconductors is become a fabulous semi, you just design the things and you subcontract to other people.

KIRKPATRICK: It's a good analogy actually yeah. But I think Oracle is making the shift but they're making it slowly because they have such an incredible business in the old legacy business model.

ODLAND: You know one thing that people don't understand and as a CEO at Office Depot I put in the Oracle Suite, it took years to get it in. You don't want to take that thing out. So people say, well he's building a business--

KIRKPATRICK: That's a key point.

ODLAND: You're building the business on these acquisitions. But these acquisitions create this linear integrated system that is very sticky. And it's hard to move.

JOHNSON: And by the way every year you had to pay additional amounts of money to "update it" et cetera.

KIRKPATRICK: Enterprise software is the roach motel is the ultimate goal.

FU: But that was preferable to having to go to the cloud. Shift everything over to a brand new platform wasn't it?

ODLAND: No that's right. These transformations are really expensive and really dangerous and hard.

KEENE: I want to rip up the script here. I learn things on Twitter.

JOHNSON: Yep.

KEENE: And one of our listeners and viewers sent in a brilliant Twitter response. Why wouldn't Alibaba and Amazon do some kind of JV? Steve? Is that feasible?

ODLAND: Look I think, why is Jack Ma here meeting every major CEO and financier in town? Why is he spending so much time in America when it's a Chinese IPO? I think the answer is that his focus is not just on China. His focus is on the US next.

KIRKPATRICK: It's also because he's not selling sharing shares to people in China by the way. They can't even buy this offering. That's one of the oddities of this whole thing. But I do think a JV with Amazon is not out of the question.

I think Jack Ma is the kind of opportunist in a good way, that would allow him to consider anything.

KEENE: It gives Bezos immediate international expansion right?

KIRKPATRICK: Well it could, I would, Bezos is not, I would be more surprised if Bezos did it than if Jack Ma did it.

KEENE: OK fair.

KIRKPATRICK: Bezos is not the kind of guy who likes to share the spotlight. Or who likes to really let somebody else make any decisions for him. Amazon more than almost any tech company has always wanted to do everything itself.

JOHNSON: All right so that's the theoretical. Let's get practical here. Your Office Depot that you ran through what, 2010, what does Alibaba mean for brick and mortar companies like Office Depot?

ODLAND: Well what people don't realize is that the office product stores, Office Depot and Staples, were the third and fourth largest internet retailers in the world. And so you know, there's, bricks and mortar have really increased their business.

So Alibaba is an access point I think for bricks and mortar retail into China, like Amazon had become an access point with their stores within a stores. It could be a big growth vehicle for a lot of American companies.

KIRKPATRICK: Interestingly one of the big trends in the Chinese internet is that Alibaba, Tencent and other companies are making investments in bricks and mortar. And in fact they're starting to build infrastructures that include offline delivery; both Alibaba and Tencent have been doing things with gas stations, with retail stores, where they build partnerships with cross ownership.

FU: Yeah it's not something that you hear about too much. This move into the whole physical space here for these companies.

KIRKPATRICK: It's a whole new development.

0754

(BREAK)

0757

KIRKPATRICK: Let's face it Apple technology is still way better.

KEENE: The ecosystem.

JOHNSON: OK is that honest, is that an analytical quantitative or qualitative--

KIRKPATRICK: I think it's both. I think all the evidence shows that Apple has a better design systems. People like it better. The software, hardware integration is way, dramatically better. Because that's the problem that Android has. The hardware and software is not controlled by the same people.

FU: I know Steve is going to, right after Surveillance, break out to the Apple Store because someone's holding his place in line right?

KEENE: Can we say thank you to our team? What a great set of guests today.

JOHNSON: Yes.

KEENE: Adam Posen was lousy, other than that.

FU: Oh come on. Steve Odland, thank you so much.

JOHNSON: Our producers outdid themselves today.

FU: Former CEO of Office Depot. David Kirkpatrick as well.

0758

[*] ***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

DAVID KIRKPATRICK, BLOOMBERG CONTRIBUTING EDITOR, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERGSURVEILLANCE

SEPTEMBER 19, 2014

SPEAKERS: DAVID KIRKPATRICK, BLOOMBERG CONTRIBUTING EDITOR

ADAM JOHNSON, BLOOMBERG NEWS

TOM KEENE, BLOOMBERG NEWS

SCARLET FU, BLOOMBERG NEWS

DONALD STRASZHEIM, SENIOR MANAGING DIRECTOR, ISI CHINA RESEARCH TEAM

STEVEN ODLAND, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, THE COMMITTEE FOR ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT

[*] TOM KEENE, HOST, BLOOMBERG NEWS: We've got a wonderful set of hosts for you to give you perspective and context this morning on BloombergSurveillance. Tobias Levkovich with us, Chief US Equity Strategist, Citi Research. We'll talk to him about this equity market that go, go, goes.

David Kirkpatrick in celebration of every big tech IPO, thank you so much for joining me it seems, every time--

DAVID KIRKPATRICK, BLOOMBERG CONTRIBUTING EDITOR: Oh I thought you just had me because my last name was Kirkpatrick.

KEENE: No, well very good. Happy Scotland to you this morning. When I look David at the Alibaba experience, everybody's going to gain a pop. From a tech standpoint, what does Fidelity or BlackRock or Capital Guardian Trust in Los Angeles, what do these big hitters do with their shares if we see the pop I think we're going to get?

KIRKPATRICK: I don't know what you mean by from a tech standpoint.

KEENE: Well from your perspective they're not going to sell are they?

KIRKPATRICK: I would not sell. I mean I think this is a company with a lot of profits which is one reason why those ratios are so favorable. And I think it is a company that has tremendous prospects. On the other hand we could talk about as we go on, there are a complicated set of issues with a company that's truly Chinese that's trying to operate globally competing with these American colossi. And you know a company that has a lot of interesting issues about finance and it's operating in a banking business.

KEENE: Right. Did Fidelity buy, to just use one name, did they acquire Alibaba because of the Chinese and Asian experience or did they buy them because they think they're going to compete in the United States?

KIRKPATRICK: I think it's both. I mean China is a continuingly huge market opportunity for Alibaba and all the Chinese internet companies. And the ratio of Chinese who are on the internet is way more than in the United States.

KEENE: Right.

KIRKPATRICK: It's still under 50% of all Chinese even on the internet. Alibaba completely dominates--

KEENE: Yeah.

KIRKPATRICK: Online e-commerce in China. So there's an opportunity there. And they want to go global.

KEENE: And you know Adam within this conversation we're going to see it open, there's going to be the green shoe with some 15% of shares.

ADAM JOHNSON, HOST, BLOOMBERG TELEVISION: Right.

KEENE: This is a different beast to institutions than any other deal you and I have seen. We've never seen this.

JOHNSON: Well for starters it's the biggest one. And if that green shoe that you talk about actually is incorporated into the deal, it will be the biggest ever in history, globally. I understand from that point of view David, just the sheer size, why a Fidelity has to be there. It's that big.

But what matters more the fact that it's that big or the fact that, in other words selling more products than Amazon and eBay or the fact that it actually can grow from here?

KIRKPATRICK: Well I mean obviously you want growth if you buy stock. So clearly that's the most important thing.

JOHNSON: In other words don't think of this as a dividend play or we've got to own it just because it's big.

KIRKPATRICK: No. I think this is a bet on the future of the global internet and connectivity as a driving force for the global economy. And Alibaba is as well-positioned as anybody for that. And that's the central force in the global economy.

0611

(BREAK)

0619

KEENE: I want to go to the froth of the moment. Let's bring up this archive photograph. This is a Surveillance archive, it's in our museum, the Surveillance museum here. There's Kirkpatrick on the left side and Kedrosky, Kirkpatrick's happier because he loaded the boat on Facebook at $38.

SCARLET FU, HOST, BLOOMBERG NEWS: Look how young you are Tom.

KEENE: Yeah I'm the dork in the middle (inaudible). This was a (inaudible) moment. Compare the froth of this moment versus what you and Paul Kedrosky helped me with that day with Facebook.

KIRKPATRICK: That's an interesting question Tom because for years I've been fascinated by the Chinese internet. I've been to China a lot, I'm lucky that way. And I've, but for years talking about it, people are like Ali- who? Ten-what?

KEENE: Yeah.

KIRKPATRICK: You know they just didn't focus on it. It's astonishing to me that the world has focused as completely on this recently obscure company as they have. I don't think it's inappropriate. Comparing it to Facebook, in the US it's not nearly comparable because ordinary Americans were bananas over Facebook IPO. And as many of the articles have pointed out most ordinary Americans still haven't even heard of Alibaba.

But could I just weigh in on a couple of these key points?

KEENE: Please.

KIRKPATRICK: First of all, you know, regulatory risk is not even the word I'd use. It's like executive fiat. That's the way China works. And if you look at how Tencent, Alibaba's biggest rival just got a banking license to be a private bank, one of the first private banks that's ever existed in China. There are only a couple ever. And Alibaba wanted one. They haven't gotten it yet. So those kinds of things are where you really can't predict what happens.

KEENE: Fabulous.

FU: All right lots of unknowns there. David Kirkpatrick one of our guest hosts for the hour and Don Straszheim, thank you so much, Don of ISI.

DONALD STRASZHEIM, SENIOR MANAGING DIRECTOR, ISI CHINA RESEARCH TEAM: Scarlet, good, you're welcome.

FU: Joining us this morning.

0620

(BREAK)

0652

KEENE: Does everybody realize David Kirkpatrick just cuts into the line this morning? Right up front?

KIRKPATRICK: I can't hold a 6 Plus it's too big for me. I would never want it.

KEENE: You're not going to get a 6 Plus?

KIRKPATRICK: No I would not consider it.

FU: The Asian David Kirkpatrick would.

KIRKPATRICK: It's not going to go in my pocket.

JOHNSON: It's a small iPad.

KEENE: It's a mini-mini. I like that the mini-mini. I want a mini-mini.

KIRKPATRICK: I want a phone. Thank you.

0653

(BREAK)

0742

JOHNSON: With us David Kirkpatrick author of "The Facebook Effect." So there's clearly some sort of iPhone 6 effect going on here David. What distinguishes the iPhone 6 from everything that's come before that would cause people to wait in lines of up to 13 blocks?

KIRKPATRICK: Well clearly people have been convinced by the Android ecosystem that a bigger phone is what they want. And I'm not even sure. I think it's surprising how much enthusiasm this was, I'll tell you though as somebody with an iPhone 5, if the battery life is better I'll be happy. Maybe it's simply that.

KEENE: Joshua Tapolsky says that's the number one thing.

JOHNSON: Battery life.

KEENE: Head of our digital operation, Tapolsky with a--

KIRKPATRICK: OK so I'm not so far off then.

KEENE: No the battery's everything.

FU: Consumers in Asia are the ones who really like the larger phones, the phablets as they call them. And this is the market that Apple and every other manufacturer is trying to grow.

KIRKPATRICK: I've been surprised that the bigger model is supposedly selling faster.

KEENE: Yeah I like the phrase a mini-mini.

JOHNSON: And the other--

KEENE: It's a mini-mini.

JOHNSON: It's a mini iPad mini.

KEENE: It's a mini-mini.

0743

(BREAK)

0744

KEENE: Here's a reality financially. David Kirkpatrick revenue growth at Apple up 79%, up 66%, up 45%, up 9%, up 5%. There's a trend there to a big blue chip, 5%, 6% revenue growth. Which is important here, the mass and the size of the existing Apple or do they really need to get marginal growth out of these two products?

KIRKPATRICK: I think they're both important. I mean this product is clearly remaking their image. I think it's, for whatever reason, they are, it's way beyond fashion. But fashion is an important part of it. Android has gigantic market share but it really is a way second class product system than what Apple has. I think Apple has reasserted it's capability to be the dominant technology producer in the world.

FU: And a lot of people believe it because they're lining up as well.

0745

(BREAK)

0750

FU: David Kirkpatrick?

KIRKPATRICK: Well you know it's also Safra Catz who's really been--

KEENE: Yes.

KIRKPATRICK: Sort of quietly the COO for a long, long time.

KEENE: Fair, fair.

KIRKPATRICK: And I honestly don't think that Larry Ellison's really stepping away that far. He's a guy that loves to sail. He loves to build Japanese houses. You know he is clearly; he has been somewhat off the campus for some time. But he's now going to be Executive Chairman and CTO. He's not going away.

KEENE: Scarlet he bought Lanai, one of the beautiful islands in Hawaii--

FU: Yes he did.

KEENE: From David Murdoch. He's buying Taiwan next week.

FU: Probably.

KIRKPATRICK: He could.

FU: Well Safra Catz is going to be one of the CEOs, the other one of course Mark Hurd. This Co-CEO arrangement Steve, I've got to wonder, isn't it a recipe for disaster? Deutsche Bank had co-CEOs and it hasn't worked out very well.

STEVEN ODLAND, CHIEF EXECUTIVE OFFICER, THE COMMITTEE FOR ECONOMIC DEVELOPMENT: Well there's an old saw that everybody deserves only one boss. In this case the company has two. But I suspect that they're going in understanding very clearly what the lines of division are in terms of who's going to focus on what. And I think the point is right, that Larry's not going away.

KIRKPATRICK: He will adjudicate if there's any issues with the (inaudible).

KEENE: Can I ask you guys about cloud? I mean Oracle, John Chambers--

KIRKPATRICK: That's the question.

KEENE: Cisco and others, David Kirkpatrick, make us smarter on this.

KIRKPATRICK: Well honestly this is the one thing you have to ask about Oracle, they have done a great job getting service revenues from the companies that they acquired with this annuity (ph) thing.

KEENE: Right.

KIRKPATRICK: But the real annuity in enterprise software going forward is long-term contracts for cloud revenue where you don't have to, where the customer has a way more advantageous position because they don't have to make a big upfront payment. And that's where the industry has gone with salesforce and others and Oracle is not there to the same degree.

JOHNSON: Isn't that what we saw with semis where the way to make money in semiconductors is become a fabulous semi, you just design the things and you subcontract to other people.

KIRKPATRICK: It's a good analogy actually yeah. But I think Oracle is making the shift but they're making it slowly because they have such an incredible business in the old legacy business model.

ODLAND: You know one thing that people don't understand and as a CEO at Office Depot I put in the Oracle Suite, it took years to get it in. You don't want to take that thing out. So people say, well he's building a business--

KIRKPATRICK: That's a key point.

ODLAND: You're building the business on these acquisitions. But these acquisitions create this linear integrated system that is very sticky. And it's hard to move.

JOHNSON: And by the way every year you had to pay additional amounts of money to "update it" et cetera.

KIRKPATRICK: Enterprise software is the roach motel is the ultimate goal.

FU: But that was preferable to having to go to the cloud. Shift everything over to a brand new platform wasn't it?

ODLAND: No that's right. These transformations are really expensive and really dangerous and hard.

KEENE: I want to rip up the script here. I learn things on Twitter.

JOHNSON: Yep.

KEENE: And one of our listeners and viewers sent in a brilliant Twitter response. Why wouldn't Alibaba and Amazon do some kind of JV? Steve? Is that feasible?

ODLAND: Look I think, why is Jack Ma here meeting every major CEO and financier in town? Why is he spending so much time in America when it's a Chinese IPO? I think the answer is that his focus is not just on China. His focus is on the US next.

KIRKPATRICK: It's also because he's not selling sharing shares to people in China by the way. They can't even buy this offering. That's one of the oddities of this whole thing. But I do think a JV with Amazon is not out of the question.

I think Jack Ma is the kind of opportunist in a good way, that would allow him to consider anything.

KEENE: It gives Bezos immediate international expansion right?

KIRKPATRICK: Well it could, I would, Bezos is not, I would be more surprised if Bezos did it than if Jack Ma did it.

KEENE: OK fair.

KIRKPATRICK: Bezos is not the kind of guy who likes to share the spotlight. Or who likes to really let somebody else make any decisions for him. Amazon more than almost any tech company has always wanted to do everything itself.

JOHNSON: All right so that's the theoretical. Let's get practical here. Your Office Depot that you ran through what, 2010, what does Alibaba mean for brick and mortar companies like Office Depot?

ODLAND: Well what people don't realize is that the office product stores, Office Depot and Staples, were the third and fourth largest internet retailers in the world. And so you know, there's, bricks and mortar have really increased their business.

So Alibaba is an access point I think for bricks and mortar retail into China, like Amazon had become an access point with their stores within a stores. It could be a big growth vehicle for a lot of American companies.

KIRKPATRICK: Interestingly one of the big trends in the Chinese internet is that Alibaba, Tencent and other companies are making investments in bricks and mortar. And in fact they're starting to build infrastructures that include offline delivery; both Alibaba and Tencent have been doing things with gas stations, with retail stores, where they build partnerships with cross ownership.

FU: Yeah it's not something that you hear about too much. This move into the whole physical space here for these companies.

KIRKPATRICK: It's a whole new development.

0754

(BREAK)

0757

KIRKPATRICK: Let's face it Apple technology is still way better.

KEENE: The ecosystem.

JOHNSON: OK is that honest, is that an analytical quantitative or qualitative--

KIRKPATRICK: I think it's both. I think all the evidence shows that Apple has a better design systems. People like it better. The software, hardware integration is way, dramatically better. Because that's the problem that Android has. The hardware and software is not controlled by the same people.

FU: I know Steve is going to, right after Surveillance, break out to the Apple Store because someone's holding his place in line right?

KEENE: Can we say thank you to our team? What a great set of guests today.

JOHNSON: Yes.

KEENE: Adam Posen was lousy, other than that.

FU: Oh come on. Steve Odland, thank you so much.

JOHNSON: Our producers outdid themselves today.

FU: Former CEO of Office Depot. David Kirkpatrick as well.

0758

[*] ***END OF TRANSCRIPT***
