Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5VM7-FGX1-DYVR-P04X-00000-00BLUMENTHAL STATEMENT ON AMAZON'S DECISION TO REMOVE ANTI-COMPETITIVE CONTRACT CLAUSES THAT HARMED CONSUMERS2019-03-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:25:21ZLexisNexisU.S. SENATE DOCUMENTSBLUMENTHAL STATEMENT ON AMAZON'S DECISION TO REMOVE ANTI-COMPETITIVE CONTRACT CLAUSES THAT HARMED CONSUMERS

March 11, 2019

Contact: Subhan Cheema (202) 224-0335

BLUMENTHAL STATEMENT ON AMAZON'S DECISION TO REMOVE ANTI-COMPETITIVE CONTRACT CLAUSES THAT HARMED CONSUMERS

[WASHINGTON, D.C.] - U.S. Senator Richard Blumenthal (D-CT) issued the following statement today on Amazon's decision to remove anti-competitive price parity provisions from its contracts with third-party sellers in the United States and confirmed that it would stop enforcing those provisions in existing contracts, just months after Blumenthal drew attention to these harmful clauses:

"Amazon's wise and welcome decision comes only after aggressive advocacy and attention that compelled Amazon to abandon its abusive contract clause. I remain deeply troubled that federal regulators responsible for cracking down on anti-competitive practices seem asleep at the wheel, at great cost to American innovation and consumers. The DOJ and FTC must begin aggressively investigating Big Tech's potential antitrust violations and take necessary enforcement actions to deter more harmful behavior."

Blumenthal has repeatedly called on Amazon to take this step and demanded that federal regulators investigate the provisions used by Amazon and other online marketplaces. On December 20, 2018, Blumenthal wrote to the Federal Trade Commission and the Department of Justice to demand an immediate investigation into price parity provisions in Amazon's contracts, and just last week, Blumenthal raised Amazon's price parity provisions and their impact on stifling competition at a Senate Judiciary Committee hearing on competition in the U.S. economy.

Prior to Amazon's decision today, the company required third-party merchants who sell products on its site to agree to price parity provisions - also known as most-favored nation clauses - that prohibited merchants who sell on Amazon from offering a lower price on other online marketplaces. As a result, merchants who sold their products on other sites with lower transaction fees were unable to pass on these savings to consumers. For example, if a competitor to Amazon charged lower commission fees to third-party merchants operating on its site, Amazon's price parity provision prohibited those sellers from reducing their prices to reflect the lower cost of selling through Amazon's competitor. In response to pressure from European regulators, Amazon stopped enforcing these contract clauses in Europe almost six years ago. However, until today's announcement, it had continued to enforce those clauses in the United States.

The full video of Blumenthal's remarks at the Judiciary Committee hearing is available at: https://lfts.senate.gov/seos/1000/mpd/ui21032019e97a4236d4b2c9d1c3755c377c490008 ; the full text of the letter to the FTC is available at:   https://www.blumenthal.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/12.19.18%20-%20FTC%20-%20Price%20Parity.pdf and the full text of the letter to DOJ is available at:   https://www.blumenthal.senate.gov/imo/media/doc/12.19.18%20-%20DOJ%20-%20Price%20Parity.pdf.

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5MBV-3JN1-DYWP-R2B3-00000-00BNY Mellon's payment woes its second big tech glitch in 18 months2016-12-08T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:25:21ZLexisNexisBUSINESSBNY Mellon's payment woes its second big tech glitch in 18 months

BOSTON: A payment processing glitch at BNY Mellon Corp this week should not be a surprise as executives inside the world's largest custody bank recently highlighted a number of problems with the daily task of moving trillions of dollars around the global banking system. BNY Mellon on Thursday declined to say how widespread the problem was. Officials at the Federal Reserve were not available to comment. The bank provides payment services in more than 100 currencies through more than 2,000 correspondent bank accounts worldwide.

Known as a trust bank, BNY Mellon safeguards and keeps track of nearly US$26 trillion in assets for clients that include the largest asset managers, pension plans and corporations around the globe. The breakdown is the second major technology glitch to happen at BNY Mellon in the past 18 months. In August 2015, the mutual fund accounting system the bank relies on broke down and delayed how billions of dollars in assets were valued. The bank in March agreed to pay US$3 million to settle an investigation by Massachusetts' top securities regulator related to BNY Mellon's problems calculating net asset values on some 1,200 mutual funds. On Sunday afternoon, BNY Mellon began having problems processing clients' payment instructions, the bank confirmed on Thursday in a statement. BNY Mellon blamed the problems on its connection to SWIFT, a global financial messaging system that banks use for money transfer instructions. BNY Mellon processes about 160,000 global payments each day totaling an average of US$1.6 trillion, according to its financial disclosures. "We became aware of an issue that impacted our ability to send messaging to and from the SWIFT network on Sunday afternoon, which we resolved by Monday morning," the bank said in a statement. BNY Mellon said on Thursday its system is fully functional and additional backup has been established to reduce the risk of future disruptions. The bank declined to comment on what caused the problems in the first place. Nancy Atkinson, senior analyst for Aite Group, said the outage at BNY Mellon would be considered a serious problem at any large financial services company. But investors seem to have shrugged off the problem as BNY Mellon shares have risen 2 percent this week. In a recent research paper, BNY Mellon executives noted how it has been more than 40 years since there has been a significant improvement in how U.S. domestic payments are processed. Earlier this year, SWIFT, which is known for handling international payments, was used by hackers to transfer US$81 million from Bangladesh's central bank to a bank in Manila. SWIFT officials were not available to comment about BNY's recent problems. "While generally reliable, the process long used to move funds globally is fraught with familiar challenges related to timing, cost and transparency," BNY Mellon executives Tony Brady and Chris Mager wrote recently in a paper on modernizing global payment systems. The executives said cross-border payments may occur in the same day but can take up to four days to complete. And there's also a transparency problem for clients, they said. "Generally, banks in the network cannot provide clients with real-time and precise information about payment status, including updates on when funds reach beneficiaries and the exact costs involved in end-to-end execution," according to the BNY Mellon research paper. For its part, BNY Mellon's senior executives have told analysts and investors on conference calls that it has been taking the lead to spark innovation in the global payments industry. The bank, for example, is participating in SWIFT's global payments innovation initiative to improve how money is moved across borders. The initiative is expected to go live early next year. (Reporting By Tim McLaughlin; Editing by Phil Berlowitz) - Reuters

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5T6F-S5V1-JB20-G05T-00000-00Bob Woodward's "Fear" Grips The Trump White House; Senator Angus King On Brett Kavanaugh's Confirmation Hearing; Twitter And Facebook Executives Appear Before Senate Intelligence Committee Today; CNN Reality Check: Trump Takes On Sessions For Charging GOP Congressmen. Aired 7:30-8a ET2018-09-05T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:25:21ZLexisNexisNew Day7:30 AM ESTAngus KingNEWSDomestic090504CN.V42Bob Woodward's "Fear" Grips The Trump White House; Senator Angus King On Brett Kavanaugh's Confirmation Hearing; Twitter And Facebook Executives Appear Before Senate Intelligence Committee Today; CNN Reality Check: Trump Takes On Sessions For Charging GOP Congressmen. Aired 7:30-8a ETAlisyn Camerota, John Berman, Marc Short, John Avlon, Christine Romans

Bob Woodward's charges that top national security staff finds themselves compelled to protect the world from President Donald Trump should, in any normal time, precipitate an almost unprecedented national emergency. The revelations in the veteran reporter's new book are so stark and shocking because they flesh out a narrative that the president's critics have long advanced -- that he is simply not fit, by intellect, temperament, and knowledge, to be the most powerful man in the world. After yesterday's partisan turmoil over process, today democrats will dig in on the issues and don't plan to keep interrupting Chuck Grassley at today's Kavanaugh hearing. Instead, Democrats will grill Kavanaugh on abortion, the affordable care act, and executive power. Senator Angus King of Maine weighs in. Big Tech executives are coming to Capitol Hill today to testify about election meddling. Facebook COO Sheryl Sandberg and Jack Dorsey, the CEO of Twitter, will appear before the Senate Intelligence Committee to discuss actions their companies have taken to thwart foreign influence campaigns targeting the 2018 midterm elections. President Trump is blasting Attorney General Jeff Sessions for indicting two Republican congressmen with financial crimes. Those Republican congressmen happen to be two of President Trump's biggest supporters.

[07:30:00] MARC SHORT, CNN POLITICAL COMMENTATOR, FORMER WHITE HOUSE DIRECTOR OF LEGISLATIVE AFFAIRS: -- do I think want to portray something that sometimes isn't reality.

I think that this president operates --

ALISYN CAMEROTA, CNN ANCHOR: Yes.

SHORT: -- in a different. I don't think there's any doubt about that Alisyn, and he has a different operation structure.

But I think somewhere where the narrative is there's a chaos and there's dysfunction --

CAMEROTA: Yes.

SHORT: -- and it has to reconcile with the fact that you have a 4.2 percent GDP. You have the lowest unemployment rate in years.

CAMEROTA: Understood -- I understand all those accomplishments.

SHORT: You have --

CAMEROTA: But I mean, I'm just saying that --

SHORT: But, you don't. But, you don't, Alisyn because you're --

CAMEROTA: The thing -- because here -- hold on one second. I just want to focus on one thing that you just said. You're putting Bob --

SHORT: I know, you don't want to focus on accomplishments.

CAMEROTA: You're putting Bob Woodward in the same category as Omarosa.

SHORT: I'm saying there's been a series of books. I don't think there's any denial of that, right? There's been a fire --

CAMEROTA: Is Bob Woodward's book in a different category?

SHORT: I think that Bob Woodward's an acclaimed author. I don't think there's any doubt about that, Alisyn. CAMEROTA: And journalist.

SHORT: But I also think that there is a series of stories coming out that say here's a chaotic White House and there's a lot of discussion about the process.

And, in fact, when you have 99 percent of ISIS' territory that's been reclaimed --

CAMEROTA: Yes.

SHORT: -- a record number of regulations have been repealed. There's another Supreme Court justice that's about to be confirmed.

Unemployment at record lows. Taxes that have been reduced and the economy growing at a record rate.

CAMEROTA: Are you saying that all of the -- that the -- I understand.

SHORT: There has to be a reconciliation to say hey, maybe this is working OK.

CAMEROTA: OK, so the end justify the means to you.

SHORT: No, no. The end does not justify the means but perhaps there's a different process that people in this town are not used to seeing.

This is a president who is a non-traditional president. He does things a different way. That does not mean the end justifies the means --

CAMEROTA: OK.

SHORT: -- but I think there has to be reconciliation when there's all these stories about the chaos without saying hey, actually, there's significant accomplishments as well.

CAMEROTA: I hear you and you've made that point, but it's not just chaos. It sounds like there are people inside the White House very close to the president who were truly worried. Who have anxiety about the president's impulses and what it could mean for the country.

The staff secretary Rob Porter, whom you worked with, stole or hid documents, according to the quotes in this, from the president's desk on multiple occasions to protect national security.

Here's the quote from Rob Porter. "A third of my job was trying to react to some of the really dangerous ideas that he had and try to give him reasons to believe that maybe they weren't such good ideas."

Are you saying Rob Porter is not telling the truth?

SHORT: I don't know that firsthand, Alisyn.

But here's -- last hour, you had a great segment with you and David in which you were talking about the South Korea element in this story and I think there's an important detail there.

This president does have a way of having -- putting out a position that's out here -- it's an outlier -- and having his staff argue out that position.

So he might say why are troops still in South Korea? Why, when they have a trade imbalance? Why are we protecting them when they aren't helping us out?

CAMEROTA: Yes.

SHORT: And it forces his staff to come say here's why we've been there since the Korean War. Here's the benefit to the United States.

CAMEROTA: Yes.

SHORT: And it gets us to a good position.

CAMEROTA: I think that that -- look, ideally, that makes perfect sense -- the Socratic method of asking questions --

SHORT: Right.

CAMEROTA: -- but it doesn't sound like the people closest to the president think that's what's happening.

Here's what John Kelly has said. Quote, "He's an idiot. It's pointless to try to convince him of anything. He's gone off the rails.

We're in Crazytown. I don't even know why any of us are here. This is the worst job I've ever had."

This is not what you're describing, Marc, of just a president who is knowledgeable and informed asking questions.

SHORT: No. What I'm saying is he puts out a position and has the staff argue out the position, and that's the way, often, he gets informed of a decision.

There's no doubt that John Kelly has an incredibly difficult job. I think we would all acknowledge that. And I know he's been frustrated many times.

CAMEROTA: Do you doubt that he has said these things?

SHORT: I have never heard -- I have never heard John Kelly call the president an idiot. I've certainly heard him express his frustrations in the job.

And he's a guy who has sacrificed an enormous amount for this country.

CAMEROTA: Yes.

SHORT: -- and he loved being in active service in the Marine Corps.

CAMEROTA: I have a question.

SHORT: So I know this is frustrating.

CAMEROTA: Did you know that Bob Woodward was working on a book?

SHORT: I had heard that Bob Woodward was working on a book. Bob Woodward never reached out to me. I didn't participate in the book.

CAMEROTA: Do you know if anyone mentioned this to President Trump and asked him if he wanted to participate because there's a dispute about this now?

SHORT: I don't know if anyone did. I don't think it's usually productive for the president to participate in these sorts of books because I don't think they ever turn out well for him.

But as far as information, I think he likes to be the decision maker and so there should have been a discussion to say he is writing a book. We suggest you not, but what do you want to do?

CAMEROTA: Well --

SHORT: That's usually the way I would handle it in legislative affairs. Like, here's my recommendation, Mr. President. What do you want to do?

CAMEROTA: And it sounds like that's what President Trump would have wished.

Here's a moment -- it's very fascinating to listen to this phone call between Bob Woodward and President Trump where President Trump says I wish I had known about it, I would have participated. And, Bob Woodward was making the case that he had told about a half-dozen people and asked for the president's participation.

And, President Trump saying what he thinks of Bob Woodward's reputation.

So listen to this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: It's really too bad because nobody told me about it and I would have loved to have spoken to you. You know I'm very open to you. I think you've always been fair. But we'll see what happens.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CAMEROTA: That's President Trump saying that he would have spoken to him and he's always been fair.

So do you believe what is in Bob Woodward's book?

SHORT: Alisyn, I've not read the book. I can't comment as to what I believe what's in there or not. CAMEROTA: But what you've heard, do you think that this is a -- that Bob Woodward is not in the same category as Omarosa and this is --

[07:35:04] SHORT: Of course not. Of course not.

Bob Woodward is an acclaimed author. I don't mean to make that accusation.

But I do think that there's been a series of books that come out that talk about the chaos and dysfunction without saying well, maybe this is, in fact, a different management style that is producing results.

CAMEROTA: OK.

Marc Short, we appreciate your insider's take on all of this. Thank you.

SHORT: Thank you, Alisyn.

CAMEROTA: John --

JOHN BERMAN, CNN ANCHOR: Interesting discussion there.

So what's the reaction of Bob Woodward's explosive new book on Capitol Hill? We're going to ask a U.S. senator about that and the Supreme Court confirmation process. That's next.

BERMAN: Bob Woodward's explosive new book "Fear" undeniably gripping the White House. The president and his allies trying to attack the credibility of award-winning journalist Bob Woodward.

CNN has spoken to at least a dozen former and current White House officials who tell us that they spoke to Woodward for his book.

Joining us now to discuss this and much more of what's going on on Capitol Hill, Independent Sen. Angus King of Maine. Senator King, thank you so much for being with us.

I want to talk about the Supreme Court confirmation process in just a moment, but I do want to get your reaction to what we've all seen and read over the last few days in this Bob Woodward book. It paints a picture of White House officials -- again, mostly in their words -- trying to protect the country from the president.

There's an episode where Gary Cohn, former financial adviser to the president, steals papers off his desk.

He says, "I stole it off his desk. I wouldn't let him see it. He's never going to see that document. Got to protect the country."

What does it tell you that there are people close to the president that feel like they need to keep him from the country somehow?

[07:40:04] SEN. ANGUS KING (I-ME), MEMBER, SELECT COMMITTEE ON INTELLIGENCE: John, I'm afraid I'm going to disappoint you because I spent most of last night preparing for an important intelligence committee hearing today on Russian interference in the election and also trying to figure out what kind of judge Brett Kavanaugh is going to be.

So I haven't -- obviously, I haven't read the book. I haven't even looked at all the excerpts. I'm going to let you talk to other people, as you have been all morning, about that.

But I'm trying to keep my head down and do my job right here.

BERMAN: I appreciate that very much. Just before I go off this subject, Bob Woodward -- you know, you certainly have read his work for a long time.

KING: Sure.

BERMAN: I don't know if you know him or not, but any reason to doubt his reporting?

KING: Well, he certainly is -- as Marc Short just said, he's a distinguished reporter and a serious journalist. The only thing I can tell you for sure is I didn't get interviewed for the book.

So other than that, I think we're going to have to judge the book on its merits and see how it -- how the -- those people who are mentioned in the book respond and add it to the canon of literature about this presidency.

BERMAN: I understand you're going to sit in in the judiciary hearing today for the confirmation process of Judge Brett Kavanaugh.

You weren't there yesterday. I am sure you had a chance to see what happened, particularly at the beginning of the hearing with Democratic maneuvering to try to get the hearing stalled.

What did you make of that?

KING: Well, you know, it was unfortunate the way it unfolded yesterday but I really am sort of puzzled by the way this is -- this is being played out in terms of documents being produced.

I was in Maine over the weekend, as I always am, talking to people and people are starting to get suspicious. They're saying why aren't they releasing documents? What -- are they worried that something's in the documents? Do they know that something's in the documents?

I mean, we've got about 10 percent of all the material that this fellow had his hands on and wrote and produced, particularly during the period when he was in the Bush White House, and I don't think anybody watching us would do a job interview with somebody when you only had 10 percent of their resume and they said well, I'm not going to show you the rest of it.

It just -- there's something fishy here and it's the way the process is being rushed. I understand the frustration yesterday of a number of the senators given 42,000 pages of documents less than 24 hours from the hearing. I mean, the whole is just if you step back a minute makes no sense.

And what bothers me is this could be the precedent for future considerations of Supreme Court justices and I think that's a real mistake.

BERMAN: Let me ask --

KING: This is one of our fundamental responsibilities is advise and consent and I don't see how we're supposed to be able to do it without the records.

BERMAN: Let me break this into two parts, first of all on the issue of transparency.

So, when Chuck Grassley, the chairman of the committee -- Orrin Hatch, who is a senior member of that committee say this is the most transparent confirmation process they have ever seen, you're not buying it.

They also say that what matters here is Brett Kavanaugh's judicial record and you have a full record of the some 300 cases that he decided on in the appeals.

KING: I don't know if that's all that matters because those 300 cases were the cases that happened to come before his court. They don't necessarily reflect the breadth of his judicial thinking.

So I think you do need a broader record and you particularly need -- what was he thinking about, for example, presidential privilege, about torture, about detention of -- all of those issues that arose during the Bush administration. How did he approach those?

And that's -- this is our -- this is our fundamental job and I'm -- you know, I'm standing in the shoes of the people of Maine who want to know who is this guy.

He's -- this is a 30-year appointment. This is -- this guy's position on this court is going to be here when most of us are long gone and it's going to affect the country. This isn't a member of the cabinet.

BERMAN: Let me --

KING: This is a lifetime appointment and therefore, it's doubly important in my view.

BERMAN: Do you feel it was appropriate for the Democrats to try to slow down the hearing with as many interruptions as they had at the outset yesterday -- that chaotic hour?

KING: Well, you know, I'm a guy that believes in civility. But they weren't being given a chance to make the case and I think they had to raise this question.

In my view, the hearing should have been postponed. What's the rush? What is it that they're trying to move through to fast?

I've read, credibly, that Mitch McConnell warned the White House about Brett Kavanaugh because of the breadth of his record, because of the length of the time it was going to take to get all the materials together. And yet, they appointed him anyway.

But now they're starting to short-circuit the process by not producing all the information that I think we need in order to make a good decision.

BERMAN: So not only are you going to that hearing today but there's also a hearing in your committee, as you noted, about social media and the elections. Executives of Twitter and Facebook -- they're going to testify in relation to foreign actions and use of their platforms to influence the elections.

[07:45:02] What questions do you think are the most important to ask here?

KING: Well, I think the most important questions are how can the platforms navigate the First Amendment free society open information as opposed to the misuse of their platforms as they were, we now know, in 2016 to inform the American people about an upcoming election.

Our whole system is based upon information. The whole idea of democracy is that citizens can make decisions based upon information that they're given.

If the information is distorted, incorrect -- just outright lies -- then we end up with not being able to make the right decisions. So we need to understand and talk to these companies.

I don't want to regulate the Internet. I think that should be the last resort.

The question is what can the companies do to protect the integrity of their own platform, and I think that's what we're going to be talking about today.

BERMAN: Right.

KING: This is one of those rare congressional hearings where it's not rogue and everybody doesn't know the answers, and the members are going to just ask rogue questions. We're really looking for information here on how we can protect the American democratic system going forward.

BERMAN: All right. You have a busy day ahead of you.

Senator Angus King of Maine, thanks so much for being with us.

KING: Thank you, John.

CAMEROTA: OK, John.

President Trump ripping Attorney General Jeff Sessions for investigating two Republican congressmen who happen to be the president's first two supporters.

Has the Justice Department ever seen something like this before? We get a reality check.

[07:50:14] CAMEROTA: All right.

So, President Trump is blasting Attorney General Jeff Sessions for indicting two Republican congressmen with financial crimes. Those Republican congressmen happen to be two of President Trump's biggest supporters.

So what can history teach us here about this episode?

John Avlon is here with a "Reality Check" -- John.

JOHN AVLON, CNN SENIOR POLITICAL ANALYST: Alisyn, yes, a short spoiler alert -- none of this is normal.

But we all know that President Trump spends a lot of time attacking his own Justice Department, but this recent tweet you mentioned rips up the principle of justice in a much more fundamental way.

Here's what he wrote.

"Two long-running, Obama era investigations of two very popular Republican congressmen were brought to a well-publicized charge, just ahead of the midterms, by the Jeff Sessions Justice Department. Two easy wins now in doubt because there is not enough time. Good job, Jeff."

Now, Trump is referring to the indictments of Congressman Chris Collins and Duncan Hunter on charges of insider trading and misusing campaign funds. Now, coincidentally, they are also the very first congressmen who endorsed candidate Trump.

Now, he's factually wrong here on this end, at least. Chris Collins' insider trading allegedly occurred in late June 2017, not exactly the Obama era.

But that is small ball compared to the much bigger problem. Trump seems to be again taking aim at the concept of impartial justice itself, suggesting that his Justice Department should take partisan politics into account.

Republican Sen. Ben Sasse raises the same red flag, writing, quote, "The United States is not some banana republic with a two-tiered system of justice -- one for the majority party and one for the minority party."

But a quick look back shows that past Justice Departments were equal opportunity indicters when it came to corrupt members of Congress. It's not a complicated concept, folks. A Democratic crook should be the same as a Republican crook. For example, Democratic Representatives Jesse Jackson Jr., Chaka Fattah, Corrine Brown, and Anthony Weiner were all investigated during the Obama administration and convicted of various crimes ranging from tax fraud to sending obscene selfies to a minor -- charming stuff.

And how about the last time we had a Republican in the Oval Office? The same principle applied.

George W. Bush's administration saw arrests and convictions of Republican representatives Bob Ney, Duke Cunningham, and Bill Janklow.

And who could forget this guy?

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. JAMES TRAFICANT, JR. (D), OHIO: And what really frosts my pumpkin, experts around the country say to solve the problem, Congress should give them more money. Beam me up.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

AVLON: Beam me up. I mean, what's not to love about Jim Traficant -- the hair, the jean blazer, the frosting of pumpkins? The 10 conviction counts, however, of bribery, racketeering, and tax evasion ultimately beamed Democrat Jim Traficant of Youngstown up to eight years in prison.

And just around this half of the last quarter-century, Bill Clinton's administration saw the conviction of Democrats like powerful Rep. Dan Rostenkowski for his role in the congressional post office scandal.

You get the idea. There are indictments and convictions of Republican and Democratic members of Congress all the time, unfortunately.

The Justice Department operates independently from partisan politics and electoral considerations. That's what helps keep our confidence in our system.

Now, other than guilty or professing their innocence, nowhere in any of these stories did anyone of real significance suggest that the wheels of justice should simply stop turning for political purposes, until President Trump.

As our own Jeff Toobin put it --

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

JEFFREY TOOBIN, CNN CHIEF LEGAL ANALYST: You know, this tweet alone may be an impeachable offense. This is such a disgrace. This is so contrary to the traditions of the Department of Justice.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

AVLON: And that's your "Reality Check."

BERMAN: This is new, this is different. That's a great point. John Avlon, thanks so much.

Back to the negotiating table for the United States and Canada. Can they get a NAFTA deal done?

[07:58:18] BERMAN: Time for "CNN Money Now."

The Trump administration set to sit down for an important round of trade talks with one of the U.S.' closest allies.

CNN chief business correspondent Christine Romans with that now -- Romans.

CHRISTINE ROMANS, CNN CHIEF BUSINESS CORRESPONDENT, ANCHOR, "EARLY START": Hey, John.

It's a critical day for the future of NAFTA. Talks resume between Canada and the U.S. The Canadian delegation heads to Washington with both sides dug in here.

President Trump has threatened to retaliate if Canada doesn't move quickly on U.S. demands. Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau insists he will not sign a deal that's bad for Canada.

The U.S. reached a preliminary deal with Mexico last week but talks with Canada failed.

President Trump has said there is quote, "No political necessity to keep Canada in NAFTA" and warned Congress "don't intervene."

U.S. business groups say the future of NAFTA needs to be a trilateral deal.

Among the disputes here, the U.S. demands more access to Canada's dairy market which, by the way, is a relatively small part of overall U.S.-Canadian trade.

But, Canada wants cultural exemptions for industries like dairy, and Canada wants a dispute resolution mechanism.

The U.S. has set on October first deadline to renegotiate NAFTA.

And ironically, John, a lot of trade experts point out many of these things that really bother the Trump administration or Donald Trump about the U.S.-Canada trade situation were resolved under TPP but the U.S. withdrew from that.

BERMAN: All right, Christine Romans, TPP looming large, even if in the rearview mirror. Thanks so much.

We are following a ton of news so let's get to it.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

AYANNA PRESSLEY (D), NOMINEE, MASSACHUSETTS 7TH HOUSE DISTRICT: It seems like change is on the way.

MIGUEL MARQUEZ, CNN NATIONAL CORRESPONDENT: The blue wave took out a very blue member of Congress for a bluer one.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Women and minorities are coming out in huge numbers this primary season.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: People in the White House recognize the risk of this president in trying to protect his country.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: This book is not so much fake news as it's old news.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: Bob Woodward has the juice here. He's got the facts.

SEN. BOB CORKER (R), TENNESSEE: If he's got a problem with Sessions, just fire him.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: The president has a --

urn:contentItem:5VMV-R0M1-DXVP-V0Y8-00000-00Boeing 737 Max crash is latest crisis for plane maker, but it's rebounded before2019-03-12T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:25:21ZLexisNexisUSA TODAYBoeing 737 Max crash is latest crisis for plane maker, but it's rebounded beforeCharisse Jones

The most recent crash of a 737 MAX 8, and the cascade of countries who've grounded it has undeniably hurt the reputation of Boeing, the plane's maker.

But whether the company is irreparably damaged depends on the cause of the accident that claimed 157 lives, and if Boeing can come up a remedy to address it, experts say.

"Certainly there is near term damage to both Boeing's reputation and it's business,'', says Jim Corridore, director of industrials equity research at CFRA Research. "But how long lasting and how deep this impact is depends on the outcome of the investigation and how Boeing reacts.''

It's the second crash of a 737 MAX 8 in six months. A Lion Air flight went down in Indonesia in October killing 189 people. Boeing has been working on the automated anti-stall system that is believed to have caused that accident, but the inquiry into what led a second MAX 8 to nosedive on Sunday in Ethiopia is just beginning.

"I believe that whatever the problems are will be temporary in nature provided Boeing acts quickly and decisively once the problems are known,'' says Henry Harteveldt, a travel industry analyst with Atmosphere Research Group.

But Boeing still has to work with investigators to come up with the definitive causes of both accidents, Harteveldt says, how they differ or mirror each other "and then determine what can they do . . Is it an engineering problem? Is it a software problem? Is it a training problem?''

Black techies head south: Goodbye, Silicon Valley, hello, Atlanta: Black entrepreneurs part of new migration to South

Deals could bring on March Madness: March freebies: Your monthly guide to food specials, meal deals and more

Facebook strikes back: Facebook temporarily removes Elizabeth Warren ads about breaking up big tech

The most recent accident has led several countries and regions including the European Union and the United Kingdom to ground the jet, though the FAA has not issued a similar order in the U.S. And so far, U.S. carriers with the most Max's in their fleet are saying they plan to keep them in the air.

The 737 Max came on the scene in 2015, and though only 350 of the planes in its different variations are in service right now, more than 4,660 are in the pipeline as it has become Boeing's most coveted jet.

"I would say it's the single most important product that Boeing has right now.'' Corridore says. "It's the largest portion of what's in Boeing's backlog and on its production schedule . . . Nobody's ordering 737s any more. It's all 737 Max 7, 8 or 9.''

Boeing has rebounded from a crisis before. It's long-awaited Dreamliner, the first commercial jet to be primarily made of lightweight carbon composites instead of aluminum and steel, was grounded in January 2013 after a battery caught fire on one jet, and a smoldering battery forced an emergency landing of another.

But Boeing "found a way to fix the problem and the 787 Dreamliner has continued to fly without incident,'' Harteveldt says

Southwest which operates 34 MAX 8 jets in its fleet of over 750 Boeing 737s remains "confident in the safety and airworthiness of the MAX 8,'' said spokesman Dan Landson. "We don't have any changes planned to our MAX 8 operations,''

American said Tuesday that it also continues to fly its 24 MAX 8 jets, and is waiting on the delivery of 16 more this year. Another 20 should be delivered in 2020 and 2021, and 40 are slated to join its fleet in 2024 "and beyond.''

"At this time there are no facts on the cause of the accident other than news reports,'' the airline said in a statement, adding that it is staying on top of the investigation into the Ethiopian crash, as it would any airplane accident. "We have full confidence in the aircraft and our crew members.''

United doesn't fly the 737 MAX 8, but does have 14 737 MAX 9 jets which it says remain in operation.

Still, U.S. lawmakers such as Senator Elizabeth Warren (D- Mass.) and Sen. Richard Blumenthal (D-Conn.) have called on U.S. regulators to halt flights of the MAX 8, '"so the pressure on Boeing and on Southwest is going to be immense,'' Corridore says.

Shares in Boeing were down 6.1 percent to $375.41 a share when markets closed Tuesday. But in after- hours trading, Boeing's stock price had a slight uptick to $376.20.

Even with its earlier dip, Boeing's stock price continued to outpace its performance at the end of 2018 when investors were worried about a looming trade war with China.

"The stock was much lower and in fact it's still up for the year. year to date,,'' Corridore said.

This article originally appeared on USA TODAY: Boeing 737 Max crash is latest crisis for plane maker, but it's rebounded before

American said Tuesday that it also continues to fly its 24 MAX 8 jets, and is waiting on the delivery of 16 more this year. Another 20 should be delivered in 2020 and 2021, and 40 are slated to join its fleet in 2024 "and beyond.''

"At this time there are no facts on the cause of the accident other than news reports,'' the airline said in a statement, adding that it is staying on top of the investigation into the Ethiopian crash, as it would any airplane accident. "We have full confidence in the aircraft and our crew members.''

United doesn't fly the 737 MAX 8, but does have 14 737 MAX 9 jets which it says remain in operation.

Still, U.S. lawmakers such as Senator Elizabeth Warren (D- Mass.) and Sen. Richard Blumenthal (D-Conn.) have called on U.S. regulators to halt flights of the MAX 8, '"so the pressure on Boeing and on Southwest is going to be immense,'' Corridore says.

Shares in Boeing were down 6.1 percent to $375.41 a share when markets closed Tuesday. But in after- hours trading, Boeing's stock price had a slight uptick to $376.20.

Even with its earlier dip, Boeing's stock price continued to outpace its performance at the end of 2018 when investors were worried about a looming trade war with China.

"The stock was much lower and in fact it's still up for the year. year to date,,'' Corridore said.

This article originally appeared on USA TODAY: Boeing 737 Max crash is latest crisis for plane maker, but it's rebounded before

Document.Content:
urn:contentItem:5XBD-CCB1-DXH2-61NM-00000-00Boeing in Focus; Shaq Speaking Out; 2020 Concerns; Earnings on Tap for Today2019-10-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:25:21ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA6:00 AM ESTArt Hogan, Omeed Malik, Sean O'Hara, Daniel KrauthammerNEWSInternational102301cb.231Boeing in Focus; Shaq Speaking Out; 2020 Concerns; Earnings on Tap for TodayMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Cheryl Casone, Jackie DeAngglis, Andrew Napolitano

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN ANCHOR: Over Hong Kong. The controversial extradition bill that sparked the ongoing protests formally withdrawn. Reports now say that China is looking into replacing leader Carrie Lam. All the latest coming out of Hong Kong this morning.

Then the NBA versus China. The season tips off with protests, while games remain off the air in China. And Shaquille O'Neil sounds off on free speech.

MORNINGS WITH MARIA begins right now.

BARTIROMO: And we've got a big show this morning. Joining the conversation, Fox Business' Dagen McDowell, National Securities Corporation Chief Market Strategist Art Hogan, and Farvahar Partners founder and CEO Omeed Malik.

Great to see everybody this morning.

ART HOGAN, CHIEF MARKET STRATEGIST, NATIONAL SECURITIES CORPORATION: Good morning.

OMEED MALIK, FOUNDER AND CEO, FARVAHAR PARTNERS: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: How are you?

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN CONTRIBUTOR: Great.

MALIK: Good.

BARTIROMO: Good morning.

Earnings, obviously, driving these markets and we are waiting on Boeing today.

Art, got to get your take on this. The Dow Industrials down 25 points. But this is a Dow component. The company's -- Boeing's much anticipated third quarter earnings report will be out in about an hour and a half. The company ousting a top executive yesterday. It looks to rebuild its image and its confidence amid the 737 Max controversy.

What would you expect today?

HOGAN: I can tell you this, the earnings aren't going to matter at this juncture. What matters in this story is finding out if there's another shoe to dropped. And then how much information was inside this company that didn't get released. Unless and until we sort of get to the bottom of that, people aren't going to care about their earnings. They're not going to care about the dividend. They're not going to care about what the order book looks like. They really want to know, OK, how long did we know that was a problem with the new -- with the airplane and then when do we think this thing is ever going to fly? It's not going to be this year.

BARTIROMO: So they're replacing the head of the jetliner business. Is this going to be a big enough step in terms of sort of the perception that, yes, this is a new day at Boeing, new leadership?

MCDOWELL: I want to answer -- why now, though?

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Again, this this is the first major ouster of an executive since that crash that caused the groundings earlier this year. It looks like, at least from the outside looking in and McAleenan (ph), the CEO, not -- no longer the chairman, is going to have to explain this. Why are you making these changes now? It seems like that the company doesn't have their arms around it yet?

HOGAN: Right. And I think that's right.

MCDOWELL: I didn't mean to interrupt you.

HOGAN: No, no, no, I think you're right. But it's also the new revelation of, OK, this test pilot, in this simulation, not feeling comfortable with the new electronic system, the new electronic (INAUDIBLE) and -- and -- and somehow that text (ph) was either sitting within the company or not, but that information coming out right now I think was what jettisoned that particular executive. Will there be more? That's hard to know. At the end of the day, Boeing's scrambling to get something accomplished so they can get the -- you know, the most important, new product back in the air. But I just don't think it's this year's business.

MCDOWELL: You've pointed this out, though, because the biggest worry hanging over these markets, not just the China trade deal, but is the manufacturing sector in this country. And the GM strike and the grounding of this jetliner by Boeing, people need to know, what is the overall impact on -- because, again, contraction in August and September for the ISM, that's why this needs -- bigger picture, it needs to get resolved.

BARTIROMO: Yes, and I -- and I think the more we see these PMI's coming in and ISM's coming in weaker than expected, it paints this pictures that things are really slowing down sharply in manufacturing, and yet these are two major stories that is actually part of it, the Boeing situation and the GM situation. So maybe -- the manufacturing sector is slowing down as sharply as it may appear.

Yeah, look, I wrote a few analysts reports I'm sure you have too, buying opportunity, aggressive traders may look at that way, there's a lot of tail risk, though, as you start to allude to, companies like southwest getting fed up and taking business to air bus, obviously things like that that could really affect the stock.

MALIK: Yes, look, I've read a few analyst reports, I'm sure you have too, that this is actually a buying opportunity for Boeing. I think aggressive traders may want to look at it that way. I think there's a lot of tail risk here, though.

As you started to allude to, they may be concerned about companies like Southwest getting fed up and taking their business to Airbus. So, obviously, things like that, that could really affect the stock if you lost a major customer like that.

BARTIROMO: Well, I can tell you for sure, I saw Dennis Muilenburg recently and I was struck by how strong and tough and aggressive he appeared to me. I said, wow, he's really riding this and he's going to survive and grow this company. That was just my instinct --

MALIK: Yes.

BARTIROMO: After meeting with him. But, you know, we'll see.

MALIK: We'll see. Yes.

BARTIROMO: So that -- it sort of it --

MALIK: Yes.

BARTIROMO: It sort of dovetails onto what you were saying, buying opportunity. I don't know, but he certainly appeared to have a solid plan in place to get through this and grow this company on the other side.

MCDOWELL: Right the ship and stop this jetliner from yawing (ph) (INAUDIBLE).

BARTIROMO: That's exactly right.

All right, Hong Kong changing course. Let's talk there for a second. The city withdrawing that controversial bill that would have allowed extradition to mainland China. This as former NBA superstar Shaq O'Neil is speaking out about the current tensions between China and the NBA.

Here's Shaq.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SHAQ O'NEIL, FORMER NBA SUPERSTAR: One of our best values here in America is free speech. We're allowed to say what we want to say and we're allowed to speak up about injustices. And that's just how it goes. And if people don't understand that, that's something that they have to deal with. But, you know, I just think that it was unfortunately for, you know, both parties and then you've got people speaking when they don't know what they're talking about. But, you know, Daryl Morey was right.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Bingo. Thank you, Shaq O'Neil. I mean it's nice to hear some refreshing comments about the obvious.

The NBA tips off the season last night, the protests by fans were there supporting the Hong Kong pro-democracy movement,

Dagen, what you say?

MCDOWELL: I love this. But the NBA needs more of this. I keep calling it. It's a tire fire. And it's still burning. So they need to get only message. And Adam Silver tried to do this after the uproar, but then you had LeBron James. And LeBron James, quite frankly, is the NBA. He drives policy. He drives the sport. And mixed messages, not supporting free speech, not supporting western values, not supporting, quite frankly, this country that has -- that gave life to basketball and lets it breathe and lets these players speak their mind.

BARTIROMO: I don't want -- I don't want (INAUDIBLE). I don't want the league rolling over because of China's bullying. It bothers mean. I mean can you imagine the stink that this has made in America. Yes, that's right, exactly what Shaq said, we -- we have free speech. And if Maurey wants to support the protestors, go for it.

MALIK: So, personally, I couldn't agree more with you, as you know. What is philosophical question here is for me is how do you balance the desire for free market and capitalism business, which we value in this country as well, with free speech? And that's the tension we're starting to see play out, unfortunately, that some of these people have financial motivations for why they're talking the way they are. I mean they -- LeBron James has a new movie, "Space Jam 2," that's probably going to want to play in China. So you have to think about why people are speaking the way they are.

MCDOWELL: Well, you talked -- well, you've talked about how Hollywood has cut virtually every movie for the Chinese market.

MALIK: Yes. Yes.

MCDOWELL: And how, if you notice, back during the Cold War, that the villains were -- where were they from? They were from then Soviet Union.

MALIK: Yes.

MCDOWELL: But you don't see that in Hollywood. And you've got to give Quentin Tarantino --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MALIK: Yes.

MCDOWELL: Credit for coming out. He talked to Kennedy the other night on Fox Business --

BARTIROMO: Love it.

MCDOWELL: And said, I am not re-cutting "Once Upon a Time in Hollywood" for the Chinese market. I am not changing one frame of it. And that's more of what you need to hear is, I'm not going to sacrifice my -- and this -- it's art. I'm not going to sacrifice my voice just to get access to a market. They're Chinese people, but it's controlled by a communist government.

BARTIROMO: Yes, and don't come here and say you have all of these fantastic things about stakeholders and, you know, human rights abuses are number one, doing well in the community is our number one priority, not profits, and then just go and, you know, open up shop in China and play by their rules that you can't even Google Tiananmen Square.

MALIK: So true. It is so true.

BARTIROMO: I mean it's -- you know, this is a serious situation and I'd like to see companies push back and say, no, this is the way we operate. But it's -- you're right, it's the money.

MALIK: Yes.

BARTIROMO: You know, like "South Park" does so well. I -- I keep going back to "South Park" because they've done such a good job.

Let's talk 2020. The Democrats. "The New York Times" this morning highlighting some concerns about the candidates. Donors are talking about whether people who aren't in the race could get in. Names that keep popping up, Sherrod Brown, Deval Patrick and, of course, Michael Bloomberg and Hillary Clinton.

Omeed, this coming as tensions between Tulsi Gabbard and Hillary Clinton escalate.

You are a supporter of Tulsi. Wow, she came out aggressive after Clinton called her the Russian asset. And good for her.

MALIK: Yes. So overdue. This is effectively neo-McCarthyism what we're seeing now on behalf of the Democrat establishment. If you propose new philosophies or new ideas that doesn't jive with the way that they're thinking, they're basically going to slander you.

We saw some of this behavior from the right wing back in the days during the Iraq War. If you opposed the Iraq War in 2002 or 2003, certain right wing elements used to say, oh, you're a friend of Saddam's. And we saw how that stifled debate.

Now, the pendulum has swung all the way to the other side, that if you challenge Democratic orthodoxy, you're basically labeled a trader. This is someone who served our country. It's preposterous, repugnant and it is actually a slippery slope to a very dangerous environment if we don't speak out against that. So that's why I'm so happy that Tulsi spoke out so forcefully against Hillary Clinton and what her and her cronies were doing to her.

BARTIROMO: Right.

MCDOWELL: If you listen to that podcast that Hillary Clinton did with David Plouffe, she longed for the day when there were just three television networks and a few newspapers. And she essentially said, when they -- we could educate -- she didn't use the word educate, but when we could control the message.

And what she -- and James Freeman wrote about this over the weekend. What she seems to be saying is, she's not upset with foreign actors interfering in the media and with the message that gets out to the American. She's more worried about her and her corrupt cronies not being able to control what Americans hear. And she did, of course, take a shot at Fox in it. But and - - but she -- and she's bitter. She's bitter. Again, bitterness is her favorite shade of lipstick. I said that the other night. She's bitter about Tulsi Gabbard resigning as the vice chair of the DNC and supporting Bernie Sanders. So she carries a long list of people who have wronged her over her life, over her career, and she keeps it in her purse with her hot sauce, apparently.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And she's going to -- she will, you know, she'll get you.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And this is evidence of that. But in terms of these -- these big names coming out, it's preposterous. Nobody -- nobody --

BARTIROMO: Well, would she ever -- would she ever run again?

MCDOWELL: No. No.

BARTIROMO: You don't think so?

MCDOWELL: It -- people in the Democratic establishment think that the idea that Mike Bloomberg is going to jump in at this point is laughable.

BARTIROMO: Uh-huh.

MCDOWELL: He's just -- he's -- he's not ready to hit the campaign trail.

BARTIROMO: So then --so then they're nowhere.

MCDOWELL: With money, yes, but --

BARTIROMO: They have to just go all in, like they are, on impeachment and try as hard as they can to remove Donald Trump because they -- they don't have a candidate.

MCDOWELL: The biggest problem is they don't have an economic message, because the economy is so good.

MAB: Aside from Tulsi.

MCDOWELL: They don't have an economic message.

BARTIROMO: That's right.

MALIK: Yes, I mean, heaven forbid you actually try to have new ideas the way that Trump did in 2016 where they elect or nominate a milquetoast Democrat, they're going to get destroyed.

BARTIROMO: Yes. By the way, she would like the control of an election the way they tried to control the election in 2016.

MALIK: Right. Yes.

BARTIROMO: The way that cabal of individuals tried to frame Donald Trump --

MCDOWELL: Here's the --

BARTIROMO: And we should point out, in that -- in that story this morning we'll have more news, Fox News confirming that, in fact, William Barr's investigation is expanding and they're going to -- and John Durham is going to talk to John Brennan and James Clapper, something I've been predicting for two years.

MCDOWELL: After the recent -- after the recent trip the Italy, apparently is what triggered it.

BARTIROMO: That's right.

MCDOWELL: By the way, I want to point out that, that Dick's Sporting Goods CEO is quietly testing a presidential bid. Who -- people -- the American people can't even name who that is, with no offense. They know Dick's. They don't know the CEO.

BARTIROMO: Right.

MCDOWELL: So I don't know -- if you don't have -- even Mike Bloomberg, he's got billions of dollars to burn and --

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: And some decent name recognition, but this is Ed Stack, the CEO of Dick's Sporting Goods, this is according to "Politico," testing the waters for a possible third party presidential run, which could scramble the dynamics. Let's see if Hillary goes after him.

MALIK: As a Russian agent.

MCDOWELL: Right, as a Russian agent.

BARTIROMO: Say it again?

Yes, Howard Schultz didn't do much, right? I mean Howard Schultz tried it and he sort of back peddled out of it.

MCDOWELL: I don't get -- that was very -- that was very -- well, he had --

BARTIROMO: Had a back problem. He had a back problem.

MCDOWELL: He had a back problem.

BARTIROMO: But I think at -- it was a little more than that, frankly, I mean because he wasn't getting past go because he was trying to be a moderate in a field that they've got all progressive on everybody.

MALIK: Right. And what's the message? That's what -- the American people are yearning for new ideas on immigration, foreign policy. We need to see those being espoused on the Democratic side. And right now, as you suggested, by and large that's not happening.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

All right, let's take a break.

When we come back, also on deck this morning, the CEO of Eli Lily is here, Dave Ricks, to talk earnings and the future of the company there. We're going to find out where the growth is. Then we're talking with the CEO of UPS, David Abney, a big day yesterday after his earnings. We are getting ready for the peak shipping season, so we've got a lot to find out from Abney from UPS.

Georgia senator and member of the Senate Budgets, Banking and Armed Services Committees David Perdue is here on the Syrian-Turkey conflict. And Hayman Capital Management founder and CIO Kyle Bass on the Hong Kong protests. Plus, my exclusive interview with Energy Secretary Rick Perry on the president's trip to coal country. All that coming up. Stay right here.

Plus, fast-tracking Brexit this morning. British Prime Minister Boris Johnson still looking for a vote on Brexit before that October 31 deadline.

Also, one in the books. The Washington Nationals clinched game one of the World Series last night, squeaking past the Houston Astros. All the highlights right after this.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Another speed bump in Britain's struggle to leave the European Union.

Cheryl Casone on headlines now.

Cheryl.

CASONE: Yes, Maria, parliament approve Prime Minister Boris Johnson's Brexit plan, but they blocked his timetable to meet the Halloween deadline. Lawmakers say that three days wasn't enough time to debate the 435-page bill. Johnson apparently now is pushing for an early general election there. The European Union is weighing whether to grant a Brexit deadline extension.

Well, the pharmaceutical company Biogen is reversing course. They've decided to seek FDA approval for their experimental Alzheimer's drug. The company had stopped testing the drug months ago, but a second look showed that the drug actually may be effective if used in higher doses.

Take a look at the stock in the pre-market. It's actually up more than 2 percent right now.

And the Washington Nationals beat the hometown Houston Astros last night, 5-4, in the opener of the World Series. Juan Soto recorded three hits and drove in three of Washington's five runs.

Meanwhile, guys, I want you to listen to this and tell me if it sounds familiar.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

(MUSIC)

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Any idea what that is?

BARTIROMO: Yes.

CASONE: It's "Baby Shark." It was being played on the Washington Nationals Cathedral organ. It started as outfielder Gerardo Parra's walk-up song. It's now surprisingly being used to celebrate his team for making the World Series. The Nationals now hold a 1-0 lead in the best of seven series. They're heading into game two tonight. That's also going to be taking place at Minute Maid Park in Houston. Yes, Maria, tonight it's going to be on Fox. Good job. You know your baby shark, Maria. Good job.

BARTIROMO: Yes. That was an exciting game, actually. I watched it.

MCDOWELL: I did too. I really -- I was like --

BARTIROMO: I enjoyed it.

MCDOWELL: I got to get in the spirit of things.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: I watched -- well, I watched the first few innings before I --

BARTIROMO: Yes, for a few innings.

MCDOWELL: Passed out ugly on the sofa.

BARTIROMO: And the first few innings were not -- were not good for the Nationals. So, you know, it was fun.

Cheryl, thank you.

We'll take a break.

When we come back, a big week for earnings. Tesla, Ford, Caterpillar and Boeing among the heavy hitters reporting today. We'll have those numbers, tell you how they're impacting markets.

We're standing by for AT&T, out any moment now. Stay with us for that.

And then spooky Starbucks. The coffee giant reveals its phantom Frappuccino. Check it out. Why you may have to wait to take a sip of that one.

Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Another big day for earnings this morning. Dow components Boeing, Caterpillar reporting next hour. Microsoft is after the close tonight. We'll also hear from Tesla after the close.

We got AT&T coming out eminently, 93 cents is the estimate on $45 billion in revenue at AT&T. We'll get you those numbers as soon as they come out.

But look at markets really flat as we await earnings news to really drive the story.

Joining us right now is the president of Pacer ETFS Distributors, Sean O'Hara.

Sean, good to see you.

SEAN O'HARA, PRESIDENT, PACER ETFS DISTRIBUTORS: Good morning. Thank you for having me.

BARTIROMO: So, do things get busier during earnings season? Do you see more interest in, you know, in trading and in markets, ETFs, at this time of the year or no?

O'HARA: I would say generally in the ETF business overall that's probably true. Not as much for us in terms of where we fit in that infrastructure. We're not building trading type of ETFs.

BARTIROMO: Of course.

O'HARA: We're building long-term sort of mutual fund like ETFs that are built on strategies that should be part of portfolios and not necessarily traded.

BARTIROMO: Where's the flow these days?

O'HARA: We're continuing to see flows in a couple of areas that are kind of interesting. One is in some of the risk management strategies that we have. Everybody, I think, is acknowledging this has been a fairly long expansion and a long bull market. And I think folks mostly are trying to think about, you know, how do I protect these profits that I've made over the last ten year or so.

We're seeing flows into infrastructure, technology, primarily in the real estate space, for example, with a product we have called SRVR, s-r-v-r, that owns the data centers and the cell phone towers as a big buildout for these five big technologies. You've got streaming. You've got AI. You've got the Internet of things. You've got e-commerce. Those things take an enormous amount of computing power. And so that computing power is going to be delivered via the data centers and that publically traded real estate names that do that. And that -- and their -- and that product is actually one of our best performers here, the sourcing (ph) good flows into things like that.

HOGAN: There seems -- people trying to express an opinion in things on the other side of that, so I think that that's all great. And then, in technology and the direction we're going into 5G and that rollout. But how about the things people are nervous about? You know, are they -- is there a way, an ETF, to express an opinion saying, hey, I think office space is in a bubble right now and WeWork isn't about to exploded (ph) or anything along those lines?

O'HARA: I mean there's an ETF for everything today, Art, you know, so you can pretty much find what you want to find if you're an active trader or if your -- if you've got a computer you can Google search. You can pretty much express almost any view you want in ETFs, which is one of the great things about the business is, you know, there's some criticism perhaps that it's getting a little too finely cut in places, but -- but it really does allow somebody to really to express any view they want in their portfolio.

MCDOWELL: It was -- that was the criticism, though, when the first -- the i-shares (ph) were first launched. Nobody had -- you know, covering those ETFs back then, it just seemed like, who wants to own -- dice up the market that much.

HOGAN: Right.

MCDOWELL: And I think every -- virtually everyone was wrong about the possibility and opportunity in exchange traded funds. And, again, you don't have to trade them. You can buy them and hold them. That's really the message.

O'HARA: Yes, I mean, they're less expensive, more -- slightly more tax efficient proxies from mutual funds. There are passive strategies where you can own a whole index or a whole -- like the S&P 500. And then there are ETFs that are sort of fundamentally weighted where you can put a twist on a portfolio. We use, for example, free cash flow yield. We has a nice little pop yesterday out of Biogen. It screened into one of our ETFs because it has such a high free cash flow yield. And so --

BARTIROMO: Yes, and they also have an Alzheimer's drug, Biogen.

O'HARA: Yes, and so we -- we had a nice little surprise yesterday in that one in terms of performance.

MALIK: So we've seen some folks talking about ETFs in the cannabis space. Have you seen any interest there?

O'HARA: Yes, there's a lot of interest in it. We don't have a product there. The closest we come to the cannabis exposure in our ETF family is in -- in a product called INDS, which is a distribution center ETF. It's, again, publicly-traded real estate where we own one name that's primarily focused on the development and storage of cannabis products. And that's actually sort of a circuitous way to get to it.

MALIK: Right.

O'HARA: But we don't have a cannabis part per se. There are a lot out there in the market.

BARTIROMO: There is one. I just saw one yesterday. It's POTT, p-o-t-t, right?

MALIK: Yes. Yes, exactly.

O'HARA: Yes, there's quite a few actually out there. And I think it, you know, for those who want to get exposure to that, I think they'll continue to see some proliferation in those (INAUDIBLE).

BARTIROMO: All right, so you still feel good about markets right here in terms of where -- I mean valuations are pretty high. You're still seeing sort of interest and sentiment strong in terms of consumers or are people worried about a recession, real quick.

O'HARA: I think, you know, the market will be 29 out of 29 time where we've surprised on the upside on earnings. I think low interest rates, low inflation, high employment, wage growth are all tailwinds on the market and they're overwhelming the trade talk and potentially the negatives. I think we'll slow but not go negative. And I think next year we'll see things improve.

BARTIROMO: All right, Sean, great to have you. Thanks so much.

O'HARA: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Sean O'Hara joining us there.

We're going to take a break.

When we come back, investigating FaceBook. Dozens of attorneys general readying to do an anti-trust investigation. Google could be next. We're going to get into it.

Then WeWork's woes. The company's chairman ready to lay out the future to employees. That's next.

Back in a minute.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Good Wednesday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo. And it is Wednesday, October 23rd.

Your top stories right now, 6:30 a.m. on the East Coast.

Another big day for earnings. That will drive markets. Eli Lily just out with their third quarter reporting mixed results. The company did raise its profit guidance, however. We are waiting on AT&T this morning any minute. Investors are also watching for Dow components Caterpillar and Boeing due out with their third quarter numbers in the next hour. We'll have all the numbers and full analysis coming up.

Markets this morning are flat, looking for some direction. Take a look, Dow Industrials actually just took a step down, down 53 points right now on the Dow. The S&P futures are down 1 point. The Nasdaq is up by 2 points, as you can see there.

Earnings and uncertainty over the timing of the U.K.'s exit from the EU weighed on markets yesterday with the Dow Industrials finishing down about 40 points at the close. It was a fractional move. The S&P was down 10 and the Nasdaq was down 58. That was three quarters of 1 percent.

Caterpillar is coming on the tape right now. A revenue miss.

This morning, as you can see, the S&P 500, by the way, is just 1 percent away from its all-time record high. Global markets this morning look like this. Take a look at European indices right here where obviously Caterpillar is a global story, and that's going to impact Asia, as well as Europe. Jackie.

JACKIE DEANGELIS, FBN CORRESPONDENT: Hi, Maria.

Yes, that was a double meet. The actual revenues for Caterpillar, 12.8 billion. That was well under the $13.5 billion estimate. EPS, 2.66 adjusted. That was well under the 2.88, expected EPS as well. Now the company has cut its earnings guidance. That's the forecast going forward. And apparently there seems to be an issue here -- we have to dig more into these numbers -- but there seems to be an inventory issue, or at least that's what the company is citing. As we have more, we'll certainly get back to you with it.

BARTIROMO: All right, Jackie, this is also a story of China. Caterpillar is, obviously, deriving a significant amount of money in Asia. You go to places like Shanghai, you see there, Caterpillar cranes all over the place.

But, Art, you have (INAUDIBLE) slowdown in the Chinese economy and you're seeing that show up in the Caterpillar quarter, no doubt about it.

HOGAN: Right, a hundred percent. And when we think about, you know, when -- what's going to be affected by the U.S.-China trade war, Caterpillar's the first name that comes to mind, right? And we've talked about the ABC's of the China trade war, it's Apple, Boeing and Caterpillar.

Caterpillar, more than any other names, has been affected, not just in this particular quarter, but since this thing started. So -- and this has been a year-long drag. And the -- and when we talked about at the beginning of the show, manufacturing has slowed down globally. And if manufacturing is slowing down globally, that's going affect Caterpillar.

The amazing thing to me, though, is that, you know, why do companies the size of Caterpillar wait until earnings day to let us know this bad news when they've had a month to pre-announce? And they know what their order book look like. They know what their inventory levels are. So I'm always shocked when a company the size of Caterpillar doesn't pre-announce because (INAUDIBLE) --

BARTIROMO: It is cutting its full-year guidance now.

HOGAN: Right.

BARTIROMO: We've got the expectations that this slowdown continues then at Caterpillar, Art.

HOGAN: Right. And you've got a triple miss. So you've missed on earnings. You missed on revenue estimates and you guide lower. You're going to, obviously, see what's going to happen. And the company's down about 7 percent right now. That's probably -- that's -- that's probably the magnitude of the move that we should be seeing.

BARTIROMO: Do you see value here, Omeed? When you look at a story like Caterpillar that's right in the middle of this global slowdown in manufacturing, and getting the impact of the China slowdown in particular.

MALIK: This is a macroeconomic play if you were going to try to trade this name.

BARTIROMO: That's right.

MALIK: You have to be bullish on what's going to happen with China in order the see an uptick in this stock, otherwise it's going to continue to be challenge, as you pointed out, for a lot of macroeconomic concerns.

So -- and you and I have spoken about this, is it deal just going to be piecemeal, or is this going to be a holistic reevaluation of our relationship with that country.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MALIK: And the way that answer is determined is how you look at this company.

They were expected to fall a little more than 2 percent, 2.2 percent.

MALIK: Right.

MCDOWELL: So earnings are coming in better than expected to the plus side, but revenues have only -- 63 percent have beaten revenue estimates of those reporting and the revenues they are up 3.7 percent so far this period, but that's right in line. So I think that it's -- we always talk about earnings, but it's that revenue growth and how -- and ultimately how that weighs on the business going forward.

BARTIROMO: Well, you can't fudge revenue growth, right?

MCDOWELL: Right. Exactly.

BARTIROMO: You could mix your earnings around and --

MALIK: Yes.

BARTIROMO: And change the way the quarter looks in terms of the profitability line, but you can't change revenue.

MALIK: Yes. No.

MCDOWELL: Right. And what do you -- and what are you doing to get those earnings up --

MCDOWELL: Whether it's accounting or whether it's cost-cutting and cost- cutting is never good for the broad economy.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

MCDOWELL: We'll get to that later.

BARTIROMO: This is the market headline of the day, Caterpillar down 6 percent.

MCDOWELL: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Let's talk about big tech for a second because 46 state attorneys general joining New York's investigation into FaceBook amid allegations of anti-trust and privacy concerns. As the attorneys general investigating Google plan to meet in Colorado next month to decide and discuss whether the tech giant has broken anti-trust laws itself, that's according to Reuters.

Joining us right now to talk more about that is Fox News senior judicial analyst Judge Andrew Napolitano.

Judge, good to see you.

JUDGE ANDREW NAPOLITANO, FOX NEWS SENIOR JUDICIAL ANALYST: Good morning.

So, look, the states have anti-trust laws that are almost identical, literally word for word, to the federal. And the state attorney's general sometimes pick up this cajole before the federal government does. I mean that's one way to look at it.

The other way to look at it is, the state attorneys general become very adept at wealth transfer. They did it to the tobacco industry. They're doing it to big pharma. Downtown here, as we speak, or in a few hours, they're doing to Exxon, to big oil, and big tech is the next -- is the next target.

So the question is, is this a legitimate inquiry for the violation of privacy -- it's kind of silly that the government is investigating people for violating privacy, because the government is the biggest violator of privacy on the planet.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

NAPOLITANO: Is this a legitimate inquiry or is this just an effort to get to -- is it a shakedown? It is an effort to get money from big tech? We'll see where it goes. But rarely are the states out ahead of the Feds in an area like anti-trust, which is almost exclusively federal domain.

MALIK: Well, look, I mean, I think this is a very interesting legal issue. So from an anti-trust perspective solely, it's difficult to see where that is because there's isn't an explicit cost concern to the consumers of these products, so they don't pay anything. However, on the advertising side --

NAPOLITANO: Right.

MALIK: There definitely is one because they're driving costs up potentially.

NAPOLITANO: It would have to be on the advertising side because the essence of anti-trust is a contract or a combination that interferes with interstate trade and harms the consumer. Now, when the consumer gets the product for nothing --

MALIK: Yes.

NAPOLITANO: As you pointed out, and as we all know, there's no harm to the consumer. But where does their revenue come from? From advertising. So if there is evidence that they fixed advertising rates, that would be a classic, classic case. That would cost them a fortune. A classic case of an anti-trust violation. But why are the attorneys general going after it instead of the feds? The feds are looking to regulate. The attorneys general are looking for cash. They go away if you give them enough cash. I'm sure that Zuckerberg and the others don't need me to tell them that.

BARTIROMO: They've given a lot of cash to Congress, by the way, already.

NAPOLITANO: Yes.

BARTIROMO: And a lot of those people are getting -- are big donors, which is why I think maybe they weren't as aggressive in the past. But they seem to be more aggressive now and they're pinpointing the issues on big tech.

NAPOLITANO: Well, 20 years -- 20 years ago big tobacco gave them 55 billion. There's -- is there less smoking now as a result of it? I don't know. Where did that money go? Probably to fill hole -- plug holes in their state budget shortfalls.

BARTIROMO: Very good point.

Will the U.S. ever look like the EU in terms of the government bite on big tech?

MALIK: Well, there they have the right to be forgotten. That was one of the biggest things that they established. Here we do, as you know, have a right to privacy that's not explicit in the Constitution. But, as you know, it's in the number of the Constitution.

NAPOLITANO: Yes.

MALIK: So if you establish that there is a right to privacy, then that's another angle that you may be able to have a constitutional claim outside of anti-trust.

NAPOLITANO: Well, the right to privacy restrains the government, it doesn't restrain private industry. There are statute that prohibit private industry. I mean the -- technically, if I put information in here about my banking, just detailing -- something with my own bank, and Apple doesn't keep it secure, they've violated a contract with me. That's not a constitutional violation, that's a common law contractual violation. But if the government gets their hands on this without a search warrant, there's the constitutional violation.

BARTIROMO: Judge, real quick on J and J, Johnson and Johnson. CEO Alex Gorsky saying in a deposition --

NAPOLITANO: Yes.

BARTIROMO: Earlier this month that the company's baby powder is safe, but then, less than two weeks later, the FDA announced that it actually found asbestos in the baby powder?

NAPOLITANO: All right, so when you are suing a large company like J and J, J and J has the right to name a human being who will give a deposition and knows the most about it. Rarely do they name the CEO. They name somebody a couple of rungs lower who has a better grasp at what's going on. You name - - you name the CEO, he gives a deposition that sounds like it's a commercial for the company, 13 days later it's absolutely defied by indisputable, scientific evidence in the hands of the Food and Drug Administration, it's a huge embarrassment -- embarrassment for them and the share price showed it.

BARTIROMO: Yes, it sure did. Later we're going to get to the college admission scandal.

NAPOLITANO: Yes.

BARTIROMO: We wanted to get that with you as well. But we're going to come up with it later because there's news there as well.

NAPOLITANO: Yes, there is.

BARTIROMO: Judge, good to see you. Thank you so much.

NAPOLITANO: All right. A pleasure, guys.

Cheryl.

CASONE: Ah, so, Maria, the changes started at Nike. The company announced that Mark Parker is stepping aside as chief executive. MCDOWELL: So it was only up 8 percent. That is -- that's a total return. So that includes dividends. It was --

MCDOWELL: It underperformed farm and construction equipment by almost 6 percentage points. And then the broad market, so Caterpillar, total return, up 8 percent. The broad total stock market is up 21 percent total return. So, again, it's been a loser. We haven't lost money in it this year, but -- so this -- people were expecting bad news, quite frankly.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And I would argue it's partly because they were expecting weakness out of China. One of the key heres.

I want to talk about WeWork and get your assessment of this real comedown in terms of the valuation. What was Softbank valuing it at its peak, $40 billion?

MALIK: $47 billion.

BARTIROMO: $47 billion, and now they want to valuate it at $8 billion.

MALIK: Correct.

BARTIROMO: You also have, to connect the dots for us in terms of the notable wealth tax.
