BARTIROMO: What does that mean in terms of a WeWork shareholder?

MALIK: So, absolutely.

I look at the ramifications for Elizabeth Warren's proposed wealth tax, where she suggests that net worth will be taxed if you're over 50 million. So if you owned less than 1 percent of WeWork when it was valued at over $47 billion, think about what would happen to you. And it also has a host of other unintended consequences. How do you value something that has no liquid market for it or isn't earned income? So we already have this issue with property taxes and we know how much we don't like bureaucrats telling us the -- how much our home is worth. Imagine going to your private stock portfolio and trying to tell you how much WeWork -- the investors didn't even know how much WeWork was supposed to be earned. So this is very dangerous.

And what actually stifled growth and innovation that people had to pay these taxes. So this is something that Warren and Sanders need to think about before they propose taxes like this.

BARTIROMO: Such a good point because what are you going to get taxed on, the $47 billion valuation or the $8 billion valuation. How do you value a private company?

HOGAN: Right.

BARTIROMO: Who's in charge?

HOGAN: And even at $8 billion, that's not a liquid valuation, right?

MALIK: Correct.

HOGAN: Unless and until it comes into the public market, you can't say it's even worth that $8 billion. So you can't tax that piece either. So that's why that wealth tax is so nice to say because it's out there. It's ephemeral. But what you can't do is like, OK, how do you implement that?

MALIK: Right.

HOGAN: You know, who's going to -- who's going to be in charge of saying, this is exactly how much your art work is worth, this is how much your --

BARTIROMO: That's right.

HOGAN: Property is worth. And --

BARTIROMO: All right, we'll take a break. When we come back, his father's legacy. Daniel Krauthammer joins us next to talk about his father Charles' final book. We will talk about that when we come back.

Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back.

Well, it has been more than a year since we lost the great Charles Krauthammer. And shortly after his death, Krauthammer's son edited and finished his father's final book, which just debuted in paperback.

Joining us right now the son of the late Charles Krauthammer, editor of his dad's final book, "The Point of it All: A Lifetime of Great Loves and Endeavors," Daniel Krauthammer.

Daniel, it's great to see you. Thanks so much for joining us.

DANIEL KRAUTHAMMER, EDITOR, "THE POINT OF IT ALL": Oh, thank you for having me.

BARTIROMO: How important was this in terms of doing this in paperback? And I guess your new preface included what you heard from readers about what your father would say about it.

KRAUTHAMMER: Exactly. I mean putting the book together as a whole was the most important thing to me this whole past year. And that was the number one priority in my life. But after the hardcover came out, as you say, I traveled around promoting the book and meeting the people who followed his commentary and looked to him as really kind of a guide for how to figure out what's going on in the world. And the question I got from almost everybody was, you know, what would your dad say about this, about what's going on now? And so I tried, in this new preface for the book, to distill that down to a few key principles of, you know, I can't say what he would say now, but I know how he would say it and how he would go by these, you know, real, fundamental principles of truth and logic and persuasion and good faith in the opposition. And I talk about all of that in the book.

BARTIROMO: I would love to have a conversation with him today to ask him about this impeachment inquiry.

KRAUTHAMMER: Yes. I get that question a lot too. And I think, you know, it's complicated, but I -- and I don't know what he would say. But, again, I know that he would say something that would not be predictable. He always worked from principles all the way out to the logical end point, whatever side that would land on. And in looking at what he said in the past about President Trump, and also what he said in Clinton impeachment, he would often say, you know, look, the truth can be two things at once. You can have something that's morally wrong but that's not a crime. You can have something that is a crime, but that doesn't rise to high crimes and misdemeanors.

So, you know, I think he would chart a path that would clear a lot of the noise and a lot of the emotion out of it.

BARTIROMO: Oh, yes.

KRAUTHAMMER: And get to the core of it.

BARTIROMO: He sure would.

MCDOWELL: And remind us of what's important. I -- the first time I got to met your dad, thank -- I'm thankful for that every day -- was at the Republican Convention. And we talked about dogs. And so I always go back and read some of the essays he wrote about dogs, because, again, it just crystallizes how we all feel about our animals.

KRAUTHAMMER: Yes. Yes, and that in -- in this book and his other book, "Things That Matter," that he, you know, he talks about, you know, his passions and his loves in life. There's tons of, you know, politics and history and the big questions, but also, you know, articles on dogs, baseball, fatherhood. Really kind of spanning the whole gamut of life. And I mean the most incredible thing to me was that, across these disparate subjects, there is a real through line and a philosophy that comes out. And that was what I wanted to capture in the book.

BARTIROMO: I bet he would be talking about beloved Washington Nationals this morning.

KRAUTHAMMER: Oh, yes.

BARTIROMO: Get their first World Series title winning game one last night.

KRAUTHAMMER: Yes, no, I was up late watching that. And I know he would have been too. Yes, he went -- he was a huge Nats fan. And he writes about that extensively in the book, actually. And, you know, he went to almost all the home games and I kept his tickets, actually, and I've been going to all the playoffs.

BARTIROMO: Fantastic. Lucky you.

Daniel Krauthammer, congrats. Thank you so much, sir.

KRAUTHAMMER: Thank you, Maria.

BARTIROMO: We will be right back. Stay with us.

urn:contentItem:5S09-SBD1-JB20-G2BH-00000-00Boeing Reportedly Hit By WannaCry Ransomware; Trump Picks His Doctor To Replace Shulkin As Veterans Secretary; Weekly Jobless Claims Hit Lowest Level Since 1970; Bond Market Outlook2018-03-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T21:25:21ZLexisNexisMORNINGS WITH MARIA8:00 AM ESTLindsey Bell, Steve Forbes, David Stockman, Peter Navarro, Rick RiederNEWSFinancial032903cb.231Boeing Reportedly Hit By WannaCry Ransomware; Trump Picks His Doctor To Replace Shulkin As Veterans Secretary; Weekly Jobless Claims Hit Lowest Level Since 1970; Bond Market OutlookMaria Bartiromo, Dagen McDowell, Adam Shapiro, Cheryl Casone, Nicole Petallides, Stuart Varney, Gary Gastelu

MARIA BARTIROMO, FBN HOST: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Thursday, March 29th. Your top stories right now 8:00 a.m. on the East Coast. Bulls fight back this morning, futures are pointed to gains at the start of trading, on this the final trading day for both the month and the quarter. Dow Industrials expected to be up of 80 points right out of the gate today. NASDAQ expected to be up 50. Follows yet another day in the red for the major indices yesterday even though it was just fractional moves. The Dow, the S&P 500 and the NASDAQ all on pace for the worst March -- month of March in nearly 20 years.

The big concern technology, shares of several big names under pressure of its fears of a regulatory crackdown. Both Facebook and Twitter are in bare market territory while Alphabet, Netflix, and Amazon are in correction territory those are trading higher this morning. In Europe this morning, stocks are higher. Take a look, Ft-100, CAC quarante, DAX Index all up with the German Index, the DAX up almost one percent. In Asia overnight, green across the board. It was fractional moves for the most part but Shanghai Composite in China was up better than one percent. Rebuilding America, President Trump is set to pitch his highly anticipated infrastructure plan today in Ohio in an effort to fulfill yet another campaign promise.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES: We're trying to build roads and bridges and fix bridges that are falling down. And we have a hard time getting the money, it's crazy, Washington will no longer be a roadblock to progress. Washington will now be your partner.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: What to expect from the big push coming up this morning. And then protecting our borders as President Trump unveils new pictures of construction of the wall, hundreds of law enforcement officials are throwing their support behind that billed out. Then hacks planes ransomware reportedly strikes Boeing. What you need to know as the company becomes the latest to be hit by the WannaCry virus.

Then this. From self-driving SUV to a million-dollar car, we've got all the highlights from the New York auto show. Wait until you see some of the hot wheels there this week. And then to infinity and beyond. We're taking you to outer space where astronauts are preparing for a spacewalk just moments from now. All those stories coming up this Thursday morning and joining me to break it all down, Fox Business Network's Dagen McDowell, Forbes Media chairman and former Republican Presidential candidate, Steve Forbes. And CFRA investment strategist, Lindsey Bell. Great to see you.

LINDSEY BELL, INVESTMENT STRATEGIST, CFRA: Great to be here.

STEVE FORBES, MEDIA CHAIRMAN, FORBES: Good to be here this morning.

BARTIROMO: Yes. A lot on the -- on the table to take up.

FORBES: Yes, there is.

BELL: A lot on the docket, infrastructure spending is huge. We're going to talk about that, I know. It will be interesting to see what the next step has to say.

BARTIROMO: Yes. And then of course, the final day of the -- of the quarter. We're going to start getting earnings in about two weeks from the first quarter, Dagen.

DAGEN MCDOWELL, FBN ANCHOR: Tech sell-off and it's not just Facebook, let's talk about Tesla and kind of dire financial straits and maybe I'm going to teaser up. Coming up guest, Greg Ip from the Wall Street Journal has an incredible article about our fiscal future as a country, won't be as care free as it was in the past and he's talking about the ability to borrow.

(CROSSTALK)

FORBES: The nice thing -- nice thing about earnings though is to get things back to reality. Markets been worried about what might happen. Earnings are what has happened, companies most of them are performing.

BARTIROMO: Yes. That's a good point. We're going to get back to what's happening in terms of the fundamentals. We have this breaking news, the President just tweeted, here is what he said this morning. I have stated my concerns with Amazon long before the election. Unlike others they pay little or no taxes to state and local governments. Use our postal system as they -- as their deliver boy causing tremendous loss to the United States and -- or putting many thousands of retailers out of business. The President just tweeted that about Amazon. Now, the President is taking his pitch, as well, for a trillion-dollar infrastructure plan to Ohio today as a proposal stalls out in Congress. Adam Shapiro covering the story from the White House with the very latest. Adam, good morning to you.

ADAM SHAPIRO, FBN REPORTER: And a good morning to you, Maria. The issue will be infrastructure when the President heads to North Coast Cleveland just outside, he will be speaking in Richfield, former home of Richfield Coliseum. He is going to talk about his infrastructure proposals because the bill essentially is going nowhere at this point up on Capitol Hill. There is no one comprehensive bill. What the President wants is $200 billion from Congress in seed money to actually spur a private/public partnership for 1.5 trillion worth of infrastructure spending over the next 10 years.

And what he's promising is that 1.5 trillion would have an impact of creating one-tenth of a percent to two-tenths of a percent GDP annually. It would create he says anywhere from 290,000 to 414,000 jobs for people over the next 10 years. And it would also help improve access to education and workforce development programs for people who would be working on the infrastructure projects. Now, Speaker of the House Paul Ryan, he said, well, there may not be one with huge comprehensive bill for infrastructure, there will be separate different building or infrastructure funding proposals in separate legislation. But here's what Sarah Sanders said yesterday about all of this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SARAH HUCKABEE SNADERS, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY: Following on success of tax reform, infrastructure is the next piece of the President's successful economic agenda. These workers represent the hardworking Americans across the country who will participate in the rebuilding of our nation's infrastructure, sparked from the President's vision and it will definitely be worth tuning in to see the President lay out that vision.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

SHAPIRO: So the infrastructure speech around 2:00 this afternoon from Richfield expected to get a lot of headlines. The other headline this morning in Washington has to do with firing of secretary of Veterans Affairs David Shulkin. Dr. Shulkin has published an op-ed in The New York Times in which he said it should not be this hard to serve your country. He goes on to criticize Washington, D.C. saying in recent months, the environment in Washington has turned so toxic, chaotic, disrespectful and subversive that it became impossible for me to accomplish the important work that our veterans need and deserve. Maria, back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, Adam. Thanks so much. Adam Shapiro at the White House. Joining us right now to weigh in on all of that. Former Reagan budget director, David Stockman. David, good to see you.

DAVID STOCKMAN, FORMER DIRECTOR, OFFICE OF MANAGEMENT AND BUDGET: Good morning.

BARTIROMO: Infrastructure plan is the focus today from the President, now the White House is talking about $200 billion in Federal money, the rest private money. Your thoughts on infrastructure funding.

STOCKMAN: I think he should forget it. We don't have $200 billion to spend. We have -- the government is actually flat-out broke, we have gone through a fiscal irresponsibility orgy in the last 90 days like I've never seen before. We are heading into the 10th year of a so-called recovery and we're going to have a 1.2 trillion deficit because they cut taxes by 300 billion and then they have this omnibus spending bill that raised it by 200 billion, it was bad enough what they inherited from Obama and now we are in the soup like never before. So they need to focus on getting the fiscal situation under control.

Infrastructure will take care of itself, 90 percent of infrastructure is state and local. 90 percent of infrastructure can be funded with user fees. We don't need to be, you know, hitting the Federal budget which is bleeding red ink and in time when the Fed is now going to stop printing money and actually going to be selling bonds. This is the worst time for him to be thinking about this. Now he is sleepwalking. He needs to wake up.

BARTIROMO: What do you say, Steve?

FORBES: Well, the 200 billion is not going to be one year, that's going to be the way Congress works, going to be over several years by the time these things get off the table. But in terms of infrastructure, 1.2 to make use for the state and local level, are they up to it? Are they willing to put fees in? And by the way, just for the record, you don't have an infrastructure problem when the private sector is involved. FedEx, UPS, no shortage of delivery trucks. Railroads, best in the world after deregulation in 1980. So the government is involved, they always have a maintenance problem.

STOCKMAN: I agree with that. That's why they should forget this. Let the private sector take care of it r or recognize that sewer and water is local, streets and highways are local, buses and subways are local. If the local people are unwilling to put it in the fair box or tax themselves, that's their choice, let them live with the consequences. When we take it to Washington, it becomes one giant pork barrel. We're already spending more on highways than ever before. We have 45 billion gas tax, less than 20 billion that goes to the interstate. The rest of it is --

(CROSSTALK)

FORBES: When did that start because when the trust fund was originally created, it was supposed to be just for the interstate highway system, period.

STOCKMAN: Steve --

FORBES: Where did it all go? You were there for a while.

MCDOWELL: But it goes for things like bypass, right? It goes -- this money that you said isn't spent on the highway.

STOCKMAN: Yes.

MCDOWELL: It's spent on things that are related to transportation, because in fact, because the gas tax at the Federal level hasn't gone up in more than 20 years. The highway trust fund borrows from general revenue so you have people who pay income tax but don't drive that much, actually funding the repair of roads. That's unfair.

STOCKMAN: I agree with that one hundred percent. And that's the problem with putting it on Capitol Hill in Congress. It's a logrolling situation. So, the beautification people get money, the bicycle people will get money, the mass transit people get money. It goes everywhere. Even to local roads and highways in the interstate system gets, you know, what's left over. So the lesson, it is so clear, the lesson is infrastructure. If you hear infrastructure coming from Washington run the other way because it 's really a boondoggle.

MCDOWELL: Well, just to point out, there was $21 billion in additional infrastructure spending in that that omnibus bill, right? Omnibus spending bill. So you can talk about hundreds of billions of dollars for infrastructure, well, they're getting plenty of money in that spending bill.

STOCKMAN: Yes. Let me give one example of that.

BARTIROMO: Well, where is that money going if not -- I mean, that is part of the money that they're going to use.

MCDOWELL: Right.

STOCKMAN: Of course. Obama had this ridiculous program called Tiger. It was another, you know, transportation, boondoggle going to local governments for, you know, mass transit systems and so forth. The Republicans tripled the budget that they inherited from Obama when actually Trump wanted to zero it out which he should have. If you look at this bill, it is the worst thing I've seen in my life. Obama -- I mean Trump tried to cut the domestic appropriations by 50 billion, these hypocrites and cowards in the Republican Party on Capitol Hill raised it by 63 billion. In other words, by the time the bill came to Trump, it was 100 billion higher for domestic spending than he wanted and he had to sign it so he could get his 80 billion for defense that he didn't need.

BARTIROMO: What about the -- what about the border wall? I mean, that's another priority of the President. And the President tweeted out, photos of construction work along the U.S.-Mexico border yesterday. 380 sheriffs, meanwhile, David in 40 states are calling on Congress to fund this wall. It's coming a day after the President floated the idea of using part of the Pentagon budget to pay for the wall, about $1.3 trillion spending bill signed last week included, you know, $1.6 billion in border wall spending. But much of that money can only be used to repair existing stretches of the wall not install a new one.

STOCKMAN: Well, I think the wall is the dumbest waste of money I heard in my entire career when I started in 1970. People come across the border for two reasons, to distribute drugs, they are criminals, you solve that by cancelling the war on drugs. They come here to work, you solve that by giving them work permits. If we did that, we wouldn't need any wall, we wouldn't have a border problem and the heart of the whole crime thing they're worried about is the war on drugs, it doesn't work, it simply drives it underground, creates a criminal distribution and that's the problem.

BARTIROMO: So what do you do then?

STOCKMAN: You repeal the war on drugs.

BARTIROMO: How do you get the drug dealers then from coming --

(CROSSTALK)

STOCKMAN: All you do is you call Phillip Morris and say, you're in charge of distributing drugs in the normal civil way of commerce that everything else is distributed. Making drugs illegal is what has created this problem.

FORBES: That's another subject for another time. (INAUDIBLE) extra billion, did you say was not necessary --

(CROSSTALK)

STOCKMAN: Absolutely not necessary.

FORBES: Or defense spending?

STOCKMAN: Absolutely not. We have -- we have a 600 billion defense budget, now it's 700 billion. The problem is not too little money, it's too many missions.

BARTIROMO: But the military has been pummeled, you know because of the sequestration.

STOCKMAN: No. They have --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: We have 50 percent of the planes in the Navy, they can't even fly.

STOCKMAN: Well, but --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: We haven't asked it (INAUDIBLE) in the military.

STOCKMAN: Maria, we've argued about this but let me tell you. If they didn't have so many missions, that they weren't buying 144 billion new stuff we don't need if we were actually repairing to defend the homeland and not try to please the world, they would have more than enough money out of 600 billion.

FORBES: So we shouldn't have troops in Korea?

STOCKMAN: No, we should be -- out of Korea, we should be --

(CROSSTALK)

STOCKMAN: Absolutely, no. If Europe can't take care of itself by now with 17 billion -- trillion GDP, you know, where are we after 60 years? Japan can take care of itself, Korea needs to be, you know, the peninsula needs to be demilitarized and denuclearized and let the Koreans solve --

(CROSSTALK)

BARTIROMO: How do you denuclearize if you don't have support, if you don't have the troops? You're saying, yes, let them denuclearize, that doesn't happen by an accident.

(CROSSTALK)

STOCKMAN: No. The reason that they have -- they're trying to get a nuke in the north as they saw what happened to Saddam Hussein who didn't have one. They saw what happened to Gaddafi who gave his up.

(CROSSTALK)

FORBES: The Koreans began their program long before Libya went down the tubes.

STOCKMAN: Well, the point is that's why they're continuing it now.

BARTIROMO: All right. We got to jump. David, great insights. Thank you. David Stockman there. Coming up. Boeing reportedly hit by the WannaCry computer virus. How the company is responding this morning amid alarming concerns that the malware could spread through airplane equipment. That's next.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Boeing says it's been bit by a WannaCry ransomware attack. Cheryl Casone on headlines now. Cheryl?

CHERYL CASONE, FBN ANCHOR: That's right, Maria. The company says the virus affected a small number of systems and a production plant in Charleston, South Carolina and despite some initial reports, the virus was spreading. Boeing said it did not cause any major disruptions. And they recall that WannaCry is the ransomware that struck thousands of computer systems in more than 70 countries around the world last year. Taking a look at shares of Boeing, stock higher in the premarket, up almost one percent.

Well, Adobe launching a new service to help companies track people across devices. Yes. The new initiative can track you on a home computer, a work laptop, a phone and a tablet by analyzing your activities . About 60 companies including Subway, Sprint, even the NFL are joining the initiative. Adobe says the service can help companies offer more personalized experiences and make advertisements less annoying. But yes, this comes as Facebook is facing mounting criticism over its handling of user data, interacting abuser. So we'll let you decide on this one. Shares of Adobe up more than 20 percent so far this year.

OK. Talk about a walk us out of this world, yes, just days after arriving at the International Space Station, two NASA astronauts are about to start a spacewalk, that's expected to last 6-1/2 hours. They're going to install new wireless communications equipment, so we're happily watching this for you, Maria. We're going to keep watching. And then finally there is this. Roseanne's return to the small screen brought in massive viewership for ABC in a breakout premier and it show wasted no time taking on politics.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ROSEANNE BARR: And most of all, Lord, thank you for making America great again.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: No.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: This show racking up 18.2 million viewers over two back-to-back episodes. That makes it the second most watched entertainment program of the season, behind the post Super Bowl episode of This Is Us. And also President Trump gave Roseanne Barr a call to extend his congratulations on the show's early success. Here is what she said about that call on Good Morning America.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

BARR: It was, you know, just very, very sweet of him to congratulate us. It was just a friendly conversation about working and, you know, television and ratings.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: He does focus a lot on ratings.

BARR: Oh, yes. He really understands the ratings and how they measure things. And that kind of an interest of mine too.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

CASONE: Yes. Interesting ratings sure especially when you're talking about states that are between New York and Los Angeles, big audience out there for Roseanne and the message of that show, Maria.

BARTIROMO: Yes. 18 million, that was incredible audience. And earlier we said --

FORBES: Rosie O'Donnell that he took after the first debate --

BARTIROMO: Right. The President and Rosie O'Donnell have had a fight for years.

FORBES: Yes.

BARTIROMO: But Roseanne Barr President Trump likes and has liked.

FORBES: Yes. And she shows there's a constituency out there, the Hollywood is not facing up to yet.

BARTIROMO: Yes. That's a -- that's a good point, Steve. I agree. All right. Coming up. I'll talk with the White House National Trade Council Director Peter Navarro. We're going to get in to the trade issues. He'll weigh in on the upcoming meeting between North and South Korea as well. President Trump's trade agenda of course and a lot more. Stay with us for that. Then the hottest cars are unveiled at the New York auto show. We're taking you there. Giving you a behind-the-scenes look before the official opening tomorrow. Back in a moment.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Now, to the latest on the Korean peninsula, North Korean Leader Kim Jong-un and South Korean President Moon Jae-in have decided to meet on April 27th. This led mark meeting will emphasize improving inter-Korean relations and denuclearizing the peninsula. Setting the date for these historic talks will pave the way for discussions between President Trump and the hermit kingdom.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SANDERS: We would like to see this obviously, this is something of a global importance and we want to make sure that it's done as soon as we can, but we also want to make sure it's done properly and we're working towards that goal. As we've said before, the North Koreans have made that offer and we've accepted.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: This comes as senior officials revised a U.S. and South Korea trade deal that went into effect in 2012, keeping the tariffs agreed upon in the original initiative but lifting existing limits on car manufacturers. Joining us right now is the White House National Trade Counsel Director Peter Navarro. Peter, good to see you. Thanks so much for joining us.

PETER NAVARRO, DIRECTOR, WHITE HOUSE NATIONAL TRADE COUNSEL: Yes. Good morning. A lot of excitement around here today. The Easter Egg hunt this weekend. So, you know, matters in state are really important here.

BARTIROMO: Yes. That sounds great. So, Peter, what do you think the significance is when you look at this meeting between North and South Korea and what that might mean for the President's trade deal with South Korea?

NAVARRO: Well, Maria, I like to stay in my lane very tightly. I can tell you two things. One is that President Trump is very actively engaged in as the head of the negotiations that will take place. My role here has been simply to operate on the trade side and I can tell you that this historic deal with South Korea will do two things. One, it will eliminate the economic tensions that we've had between our countries because of the trade deficit. And two, it will allow us from a National Security point of view that work much closer together and we've been very close for many, many decades now. I think what I find most interesting on the home front about this deal is how it affects working men and women here in America.

If you think about for example one of the elements of the agreement is this thing about light trucks. We were able to extend the ability to levy a tariff on light truck through 2041. And that means, real jobs and you got the ford F-Series, you've got the -- you got the Ram truck, you got the Chevy Silverado and all these things and building places like Flint, Michigan, Dearborn, Michigan, Warren, Michigan. And who says tariff don't work because that tariff that was put in place actually by President Lyndon Johnson has been one of the most successful in terms of building the vibrant auto industry that's important not just for manufacturing base but for defense industrial base. So President Trump visionary saw a problem coming that was going to hammer Michigan and other states making these trucks and parts, and he solved that problem.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

NAVARRO: And the rest of the deal of course has all sorts of great things in it looking forward that are innovative and we think it's really way to keep the trade peace as we say.

BARTIROMO: The pushback has been that it's a managed deal, it's not necessarily opening new trade with South Korea or free markets but more so managing an existing relationship.

NAVARRO: Yes. I've heard that. Two things there. One is that countries around the world have used tariffs very effectively to keep us out and to build up their own manufacturing base. And in the case of light trucks, it's a poster child for how tariffs can be good. In January we put tariffs on solar and washing machines to President Trump's leadership and what do we get? We got to flood new investment. But we're also really strongly committed to free markets and fair and reciprocal trade. And the biggest problem we've had with Korea on the trade deficit is autos and auto parts. It's 80 percent of the deficit. And so what we've done there is a combination of get the South Koreans to lift their quotas on the cars we that can send to them. At the same time they're going to lower these nontariff areas which are really insidious in the world trade environment.

BARTIROMO: Right.

NAVARRO: They used things like bogus safety standards, bogus environmental standards to keep out cars in the United States that fully meet our own safety standards which are probably higher than theirs. So it's a great thing. And of course, we've got -- we've got a currency provision and the side agreement and we got a great agreement mutually with South Korea on steel. So, it's all good.

BARTIROMO: Let me ask you about -- let me ask about China, Peter, because China is obviously wishing -- issuing a warning to the United States not to start protectionist practices across the globe by increasing tariffs and we know that it is being written right now in terms of concessions that we might see. What is the list of products that will be eligible for tariffs as it relates to China?

NAVARRO: Well, again, I want to stay in my lane there and that's the purview of the Ambassador Robert Lighthizer but I can tell you that what we're doing is a matter of policy, is targeting what's called the China 2025 industries of the future which China has specifically targeted in government documents and they said hey to the rest of the world. We're taking those industries from you and we're going to do it through a bunch of industrial policies that violate free market principles. And what we're doing with the Section 301 investigations to the vision of President Trump and Ambassador Lighthizer is defending ourselves against that. So that's the thrust to that policy and we believe we can move forward with the Chinese and have a stable international trading environment but we're a long way from that because they do things like steal our intellectual properties.

BARTIROMO: Let me -- let me ask --

NAVARRO: Of course, the technology transfer.

BARTIROMO: Let me ask you this. I know that technology transfer, we've talked a lot of that on this program, Peter, and a lot people get that that China is trying to acquire out technology and be better at it than us frankly for all of these industries. But when you're looking at the investment restrictions that are to come out and I know they're being written right now in terms of China investing in United States. I mean, China has 10 sectors that are off limits to foreigners. Are we going to have something similar like that? Are we going to have restrictions in terms of financial services, semiconductors, and restrictions of how much China can acquire?

NAVARRO: Yes, I think it's important to remind American people why China is so different from everybody else. Every other country that goes in and invests in foreign countries goes there to basically earn a fair profit and a fair rate of return for their shareholders. What China does is it uses its state money, brings in trillions of dollars in the United States, in Europe, and other countries. They don't care about earning a return, they just come here pay high premium, basically take our technology through acquisitions, mergers, and other means -- venture funding.

Silicon Valley right now, they're just going in there and buying up really key technologies not just for economic future but for our military defense. And so, we need to be very careful about that. And the Chinese, unfortunately, have been transparent dating back to 2006. They've told us what they're going to go after, they told us how they're going to do it. A lot of ways going you're going to do it basically don't fit to rules of the trading environment. And President Trump, unlike every other president before him dating back to end of World War II, is actually standing up not just for the American people but for American business in our defense. So, this is important.

BARTIROMO: It sounds like we will see restrictions. It sounds like we will see restrictions on investments in those industries.

NAVARRO: That is the purview of Secretary Mnuchin and I want stand my own. What I'm saying here simply to you, Maria, is that we've identified the problem that's significant that raises issues of both economic security and national security. And we have to ask ourselves: I mean, do we want Chinese state-owned enterprise to come in and buy our artificial intelligence starts-ups in Silicon Valley, take them back to China and use them?

BARTIROMO: I was asking specifically about financial services and semiconductors, Peter.

NAVARRO: Sorry, I didn't hear that. Those are those are all sectors that are on the table for discussion, and Ambassador Bob -- Robert Lighthizer and Secretary Mnuchin are leading those discussion, and I stay out of their lane.

BARTIROMO: And I know that Ambassador Lighthizer is also working on the NAFTA deal. But Peter, let's face it, we've got elections in Mexico a couple weeks. The U.S.-Canada-Mexico, still into throws of these NAFTA negotiations. It's hard for me to expect a deal on NAFTA this year. You got the Mexican elections and then you've got that midterms elections in the U.S. Are we basically going to see a NAFTA redo after the midterms?

NAVARRO: Well, there've been six or more meetings with the three principals involving literally hundreds of negotiators. And I agree with your assessment that it's going to be very difficult as closer we get to Mexican elections.

BARTIROMO: Right.

NAVARRO: But there's optimism. And I can tell you this: Ambassador Robert Lighthizer and President Trump would get a good deal. They're the two people that'll get it for us.

BARTIROMO: Peter, good to see you, sir. Thanks so much.

NAVARRO: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Peter Navarro. We'll be right back.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Good Thursday morning, everybody. Thanks so much for joining us. I'm Maria Bartiromo and it is Thursday, March 29th. Your top stories right 8:35 on the East Coast. Stocks looking to rebound this morning. Take a look, futures indicating the Dow will open up 70 points, about a third of a percent higher; the NASDAQ up two-thirds of a percent higher, 39 points higher; and the S&P, up a third of a percent as well.

Breaking news on the economy right now: personal income and spending both rising, that was in line with expectations, up four-tenths of a percent and two-tenths of a percent respectively. Initial jobless claims were down in the latest week to 215,000. And today marks the final trading day of the month and the quarter. The Dow and S&P500 are on track for their first quarterly decline in more than two years. Stocks closing today; yesterday lower, fractionally so. The NASDAQ was worst performer, it was down nearly one percent.

We are watching market reaction to latest round of economic data. As you just heard, personal income coming in, up four-tenths, and personal spending up two-tenths of a percent. And the core PCE rate, which the Federal Reserve watches closely was up 1.6 percent again, in line with the expectations. Joining me right now is Rick Rieder, Blackrock's Global Chief Investment Officer of fixed income with $1.7 trillion in assets under management. Great to see you, Rick.

RICK RIEDER, GLOBAL CHIEF INVESTMENT OFFICER, BLACKROCK: Good to be here.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much for joining us. So, we just had some economic data. Do you one of PCE? I mean, how focused are you on that in terms of what it tells us about inflation?

RIEDER: Very, very importantly. In fact, as you described on air, the Fed is -- that's the Fed's number one metric. And one of the things that I think people don't recognize enough, the Fed's not really that far behind curve -- that 1.6 percent, the Fed's target is two. So, the Feds said, no raise -- core CPI is about 1.8. So, we watched Core P.C. very, very closely. If you start, which we think will happen this year, they'll accelerate over to, but when you think about that, you put that in a historic context, that's scary a number. So, the Feds are going to keep moving, but there are no raise, and there are no rush to do it.

BARTIROMO: So, let's talk about that, because yesterday, I was surprised to see this new speculation that the fed might raise rates five times this year, is that what you think?

RIEDER: No, no. I mean, part of this number -- the fed's going to keep going, they're going to move in the dots, there are some ambiguity around there; they go three times, four times. You know, I think one of the things that the markets are focused on is not necessarily the speed, it's where is the ultimately destination they're going and how restrictive are they going to be. And one of the things that markets got nervous about is they'll keep moving, they'll keep moving on a steady pace. They don't need to pick up pace and they don't need to go five times and pick up the pace. But it's what is the destination and that's one of the things that the markets are focused on, but they don't need the race.

BARTIROMO: Well, this is what -- I mean, there's been so much upset about higher rates, about the possibility of inflation, has this been all overdone? You like equities here, don't you?

RIEDER: I do. I think they will ultimately go higher. There's something -- I don't know if I have chart that we can show.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Let's bring up Rick's chart.

RIEDER: There's something that's really powerful today and what people, I don't think, considered enough is that the last five years, we've been in this environment where we've been at zero interest rates. The funds rate is set at zero. The front end of the yield curve, so two-year treasury has been at zero. So, where do you go to get your yield? You've had to go -- I mean, this chart extraordinary. By the way, if you look at this chart versus history and go back to '06, '07. (INAUDIBLE) you think about what's happening, you can now buy the front end of yield curve cheaper than dividend and the dividend payout. You look at -- I mean, it's pretty ominous when you at 06, 07. By the way, I don't think when an ominous period today, but the alternative for other -- for equities, the alternative for how you do a credit risk, or how you think bonds, high- yield bonds, et cetera. All of a sudden, you could buy the front end of the yield curve. And if you don't think the Fed is going to run faster, it's incredibly a trap today. When people -- when we finished the year, I don't think rates are moving that much higher. But I do think you can move up 10 and go to three and quarter 3-1/2. With that front end to the yield curve is all of a sudden, an alternative investment to other things that I carry really well. If I'm individual investor, I can just buy two-year treasuries. And for the first time in five years, I actually get above the rate of inflation, which is terrific.

BARTIROMO: Above the rate of inflation but not out of this world high rates. You're still -- low rates?

RIEDER: Totally.

BARTIROMO: Yes.

RIEDER: Totally. And the point being, people focus on the 10-year treasury, and I say if we get three percent 10-year, my God, it's all over. The 3-year -- you know, the 10-year treasury, we think, will probably go to three and quarter this year, but we think of more in the second half of the year, but it's not that scary -- we're not talking about historically high rates.

BARTIROMO: Well, I mean, 2.76 percent is where we are right now, and any time we get close to three percent, this market sells off.

RIEDER: Yes, I don't really understand. It's like, 2.95 is OK, but don't get three.

BARTIROMO: Right.

RIEDER: Yes, I don't really understand that. I mean, there is a difference. By the way, the front-end yield curve is a big difference because it means that now I don't take any risk, I don't have to take 10- year treasury risk. That is a big deal. But listen, if rates move up gradually, then markets will be fine.

BARTIROMO: So, you think there are values in equities right now?

RIEDER: I do, I do. I think.

BARTIROMO: Tell us about that.

RIEDER: So, I think what ends up happening is, you know, people, whether it's tech or tariffs, there is the short-term data that I think spooks people in terms of how much risk. And people have taken a lot of risk in January; people were building a lot of risk. Evaluations in the equity market today are not that bad. I mean, there are places, I would argue, you know, I'm not in, you know, fixed income. But when you think about, you know, somewhere where the financials are, and some of the multiples, and some of these. They're actually pretty attractive today. You know, so some complement: I could buy treasuries in the front end carry well, and then there's parts of the equity market and I could take some risk to build a balanced portfolio.

BARTIROMO: Especially going into the reporting season, which we are about to enter. The first quarter reporting is: we were expecting corporate earnings to be up 16.5 percent for the first quarter.

RIEDER: Not only earnings. I mean, we focus, we look a lot of revenues to get a sense for what is the forward growth. The revenues are going to be pretty substantial. Meaning, you're going to have what we think will be durable earnings. And I'm a big believer of this tax bill which people talk about enough the ability to write off your direct expensing. And I could, some said, company you're seeing capex surge, it means growth will continue to be good, earnings will continue to be good. And by the way, 21 percent tax rate means that these numbers going to look pretty positive for a while.

BARTIROMO: Oh, yes. I mean, going from a corporate rate of 40 percent -- close to 40 percent to 21 percent is a huge deal. And you think this is going to have legs? It's not just going to be an overnight success, but we're going to see an impact to corporates for a year or two.

RIEDER: I think people underestimate the cash flow benefit for companies, particularly financials, particularly health care, managed care, et cetera. The flow-through because Capex writing off interest, writing off (INAUDIBLE) is a big deal, and I will spur spending. Now, that being said, there's one that I think is a concern. The amount of debt we're putting in the system is a lot.

BARTIROMO: Yes, and treasury is going to have to borrow a trillion dollars this fiscal year to cover government spending, lower tax revenue. How does that impact the bond market?

RIEDER: It's a big deal. By the way, (INAUDIBLE) and then ultimately the equity market. You know, listen, there is some part which have driven short term rates -- worth pumping so many treasury bills. We're going to do bills. We get two years, three years, five years. It's a lot of debt. For the next three years, the trillion dollars of additional net debt that has to be funded by marketplace, it's a lot. It's what will push -- you know, inflation is not scary. It's what is going to push rates moderately higher. You know, what will be key is we're going to absorb that various ways to make money and fixed income, you've got be really careful with how much interest rate exposure you have with this much issuance is going to come out of the market.

BARTIROMO: So, how do you make money and fixed income right now?

RIEDER: So, first of all. I mean, you know holding the front of the -- so then, emerging markets are, you know, people have been blown away. Why would all this volatility? Emerging markets aren't moving around that much. It's because they don't have leverage to use at. And they're giving you substantial yield. So, we like only that -- we like buying a lot of secured assets. So, commercial mortgages, not agencies, carry really well, don't take a log of yield curve for us. You can make in fixed income.

BARTIROMO: Let me get your take on the Libor. The journal is reporting that the race, "Rapid Rise", they're highlighting that. What do you think are the implications of that?

RIEDER: It's huge. I mean it today, it is the financing of the market poise. Some of them has to do with the patriation, it's a short term in Fox. I know that it has to do with the treasury bill, which and set anything done. And then, they're also financing as some of the foreign banks, because the tax bill, some impact to that. It's incredibly important because it's the gearing of how financial system works. It doesn't get focus on enough. Our senses, it'll start to stabilize here. We don't think it's come back a lot, but it will stabilize. And a lot of the pressure is from the village who slaughtered the pressure from the repatriation. We'll shut to stabilize. But people underestimate how big a deal. There's so much important (INAUDIBLE) in the financial system.

BARTIROMO: Rick, thanks so much for your insight.

RIEDER: My pleasure.

BARTIROMO: I'll see you on Wall Street this weekend. Rick Rieder of Blackrock. We'll be right back.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Technologies got a bid this morning. Tech stocks are higher after the sell-off recently. Nicole Petallides on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange watching that and what should be boomer opening this morning, Nic.

NICOLE PETALLIDES, FBN ANCHOR: I know, Maria, well, this is the last trading days you've been hinting and all the last quarters were so great, there were so much window dressing happening now because they didn't have to do that in all those prior -quarters. I got a note from over at Wedbush, Joe Colina who said as far as tech, the triple Qs were looking to the upside this morning but they were held hostage yesterday. But they expected this move and they're going to be watching the FANG Index, NVidia, Netflix, Facebook, Google, and the triple Qs need to reclaim the 100 days sooner than later. Quick look at some of the details here. So, Facebook in the premarket is up one percent.

Snap is looking higher, Amazon to the downside, Facebook cutting ties with some of the data brokers, this -- those data brokers gather your information for advertisers, they're making all kinds of changes. Before the month, Facebook is down 14 percent, and then Snap is cutting 100 employees. They've been -- it's their latest round of downsizing. Snap over the last 52 weeks, down 30 percent roughly.

And then there is Amazon, and look at the tweet from our president, President Trump, stating his concerns once again about Amazon's -- he's been saying it since the election, that they pay little or no taxes, they use the postal system as their delivery boy. Amazon a bit to the down side this morning. Before the month, it's down five percent, but certainly, we feel the White House steeping in to try and curb the dominant growth that we've been seeing for Amazon. But big picture, tech have been the story of this month. Back to you.

BARTIROMO: All right, Nic, thank you so much. Amazon not catching a bid, stock is down as you just told us, Nic. Joining us to weigh in "VARNEY & COMPANY" host, Stuart Varney. Stu, good to see you.

STUART VARNEY, FBN HOST: You, too, maria.

BARTIROMO: The President says Amazon is putting thousands of retailers out of business and that's just one part of the problem he has with Amazon.

VARNEY: Yes, he's clearly going after them, and that's a fact on taxes, on retailers, et cetera, et cetera.

BARTIROMO: We knew that would come, right, Stu?

VARNEY: I don't know whether it would -- I knew it would come from the President. I'm not surprised by it. After all, The Washington Post which is a principal Trump-hating vehicle is owned by Jeff Bezos, who runs Amazon. So, there is sort of a nasty connection there between the two, so I'm not that surprised, but I think this is all a precursor to a reworking of our antitrust laws. I think that the big tech companies have created quite a few enemies and a lot of concern about their power in all kinds of industries. And I think those concerns are going to come to a head with some kind of antitrust action against one or all of them. What form it takes, I don't know, because you'll have to rework the antitrust laws to take account of the 21st century as opposed to the late 19th century or early 20th century, but I think that's what's coming. And I think that's what's spooking the markets because if you really do apply some form of antitrust law to these giants, they're going to pay a price.

BARTIROMO: Yes, well, they're more -- they're more powerful and more influential than they've ever been.

VARNEY: Oh, absolutely so, yes. I mean, look how much of the stock market rally is concentrated in the five tech stocks. It's 40 percent, something like that. Extraordinary.

BARTIROMO: Yes, exactly. And tech is 25 percent of the S&P500, right?

MCDOWELL: It's 27.

BARTIROMO: 27 percent. Stu, we'll see you in about 10 minutes.

VARNEY: Yes, you will.

BARTIROMO: Thank you so much. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins top of the hour at 9:00 a.m. Eastern right after MORNINGS WITH MARIA. But first, excitement revs up for the New York auto show. We've got a sneak peek at the coolest wheels hitting the road. That's next.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. NissanRenault looking to make their marriage official. The automakers have had an alliance for two decades and reports say now they may officially merge. This comes, as car companies show off their new models at this year's New York auto show. That's where we find foxnews.com Automotive Editor, Gary Gastelu. Gary, good morning to you.

GARY GASTELU, FOXNEWS.COM AUTOMOTIVE EDITOR: How you doing, Maria? You know, if you've been in the mall parking lot lately, you may not be surprised that pretty much all the cars here that are being revealed are SUVs. There's a new Subaru Forester, new Toyota RAV4 which was the best- selling vehicle in America last year that's not a pickup. And the showstopper was a pickup based on an SUV, it's the new Volkswagen Atlas Tanoak concept. And this is one that they're going to be thinking about making in Tennessee if enough people like it. More car-like than a pickup truck is going to be, it's more for lifestyle buyers, but if enough people raise their hand, they are going to go ahead and make this car because there's definitely a market for this sort of thing. And based on the attention it's been getting here, it's certainly a big hit.

You know, it's almost more unusual to see a car at a car show these days, and I've got the most unusual car at this show right now. It's the Rimac Concept Two. This is an all-electric super car that's made in Croatia of all places. It has 2,000 horsepower, which means it's about three times more powerful than the most powerful Teslas, it had a top speed of 258 miles an hour, will be the quickest car in the world when it goes on sale. And it can drive itself, at least the company says it can. We'll see about that. It is the Concept Two. They've made the Concept One which they have already sold. So, this one is definitely the real thing, 150 of them for about a million dollars a pop.

BARTIROMO: Wow. That is -- you know, that is funny though that you would say that. It's hard to see a car at a car show but that certainly a hot wheels there. But the trend has once again been big.

GASTELU: Absolutely, Cadillac has got the new XTS, it's the Lincoln Aviator which is probably going to be one of its best-selling vehicles coming up soon. You know, the fuel economy is better, they ride better, people are moving up into the bigger vehicles. And there's no stopping that right now from what the people here are saying.

BARTIROMO: Gary, thanks so much. Gary Gastelu is up the New York auto show. We're going to take a break, then we got final thoughts from this all-star panel. Stay with us.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. Final thoughts from our all-star panel right now. Lindsey Bell?

BELL: That's 16-1/2 percent cue on earnings numbers we're talking about. We need to remember this is the first quarter that we're going to have tax reform in those numbers. We'll see is it enough, did they move the numbers enough or not?

BARTIROMO: Yes. And then we're going to watch guidance, obviously. We're expecting 18 percent growth in earnings for 2018. Steve Forbes?

FORBES: We should have relief that we haven't had a trade war. That South Korean agreement, not great but we didn't blow it up. Big thing, next thing we look at is NAFTA. We get the same kind of agreement there. Wipe your brow. Please stake a big one.

BARTIROMO: Not going to happen before the Mexican elections.

FORBES: That's going to be huge and who's going to win that in Mexico? We could have a bad actor there, another (INAUDIBLE) type.

BARTIROMO: Yes, that's right, the lefty guy. Dagen?

MCDOWELL: So, instead of going on Facebook and liking some Hillary Clinton meme that your mother posts, call her on the phone and tell her you love her. I think that -- maybe this is a warning sign that the relationships that we build and develop online are not the healthiest.

BARTIROMO: Yes, a good point. Great panel, everybody. Thanks for being here. Wishing everybody at their happy Easter. Dagen's got you covered tomorrow. "VARNEY & COMPANY" begins now. Stu, take it away.
